Director Wes Anderson releases a quirky, almost storybook tale of adolescent love in a bygone era.
The Amazing Spider-Man has its good points, the primary leads and romance, but lacks fluidity and presence of a great villain.
The Dark Knight Rises is a thundering finale to what is, undoubtedly, the greatest comic adaptation to film.
There's a simple rule to follow in a good recipe. Don't mess with the ingredients or what you get will not be as good as the original.
It's deja vu all over again.
Lawless has its moments with a top notch cast, but is not up to par with Hillcoat's previous work.
Tsui Hark takes Hollywood dead on with a bold, special effects laden, kung fu epic.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Anderson's filmmaking skills are tremendous, but he suffers here under his own conceit.
Who would have guessed that Karl Urban would be the baddest-ass mofo of 2012 so far?
Looper is a thinking man's science fiction film with a bold plot that grabs you from the opening frame.
Taken 2 is a dud.
Argo is the first film I've seen this year that warrants an Oscar nomination for Best Film.
Tyler Perry, who made his considerable fortune in drag as Madea, was wise to embrace a film that pulled no punches and shows he can be a bad ass on screen.
Director Rupert Sanders is quite skilled in his feature film debut. He succeeds in creating a fantasy world with a striking dichotomy of darkness and light.
Akin to a skit that never ends
Man on a Ledge is the kind of movie where you need to check your brain at the door and enjoy a brief respite from reality.
Red Tails is more of a summer action film, filled with patriotic fervor and a broad spotlight on the pioneer black fighter pilots of the US military.
Pirates 4 is a shining example of Hollywood's ten pages and a bang theory.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A must see for all ages, kids and adults will love this movie.
A colossal disappointment, The term dialed-in should be replaced with The Hangover 2.
Cornball dialogue and poor characterizations drag down the successes of the incredible visual effects.
A brainless comedy to escape from the grind.
The animation is superb, but the length and sledgehammer delivery takes Cars 2 down to second gear.
Transformers: Dark of the Moon is a full on robot orgy of violence and destruction.
J.K. Rowling's boy wizard gets a spectacular, yet not entirely satisfying finale.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Captain America succeeds grandly where the others failed.
Will somebody please stand up and give me some different aliens.
Rise of the Planet of the Apes could have been a great film...if it wasn't so uneven.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A kid-friendly special effects romp that will either give you a few chuckles or bore you senseless.
That rare film that exceeds your expectations by a mile.
Warrior is an epic, beautiful film, a must see!
Straw Dogs has its flaws, but is a visceral experience and definitely worth seeing.
Craig Brewer's adaptation cleverly gives several nods and winks to the first film, but also has a modern sensibility that every teenager today will understand.
Harold and Kumar is gleefully offensive to all. You'll never look at babies or waffles the same way again.
Clint Eastwood's biopic of J. Edgar Hoover has elements of a good drama, but merely brushes over the various controversies in a suprisingly humdrum narrative.
Henry Cavill is on the verge of stardom.
I found Hugo to be unrewarding, despite its impressive look.
Sleeping Beauty's frank subject matter and stark portrayal of a sexually blase college student is certainly interesting, but not nearly as much as expected.
A nonsensical, dazzling jumble of wild action scenes and formulaic characters.
The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo is that rare hard-R rated studio film that expertly weaves story and character development into the lascivious subject matter.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Poetic, thrilling, heartwrenching, Spielberg has made his finest film in a decade; and maybe the best film of 2011.
A disappointing and nonsensical remake...
The new age spiritualism behind the story is flogged for too long and ultimately isn't that rewarding. However, the audacity of Cloud Atlas makes it a must see for any real fan of cinema.
Skyfall represents the new standard in one of cinema's longest running franchises. It is a deeply personal, exquisitely shot film that had me mesmerized from the opening scene.
Daniel Day-Lewis plays Lincoln as a true mid-westerner, a wry, twinkle-eyed statesman that understood how conviction and likeability could affect the hearts of men. This man has no equal as an actor.
Riddick disappoints.
Prisoners starts off promising; but peters away its substantial tension with a drawn out ending and somewhat obvious villain.
Metallica shreds their way unto IMAX screens in a rousing spectacle.
Gravity reminds us how breathtaking cinema can be in its scope and realism.
This harrowing story of the worst of humanity is deceptively simple and straightforward. 12 Years a Slave is an essential film for all to see.
It seems impossible that a stellar cast under the guidance of such a gifted filmmaker and writer would be a step above awful.
A dark tale about the militarization of youth, Director Gavin Hood delivers a solid adaptation of the science fiction classic.
While Hemsworth is buff and brooding as Thor, Tom Hiddleston steals every scene as the contemptuous Loki.
Nebraska unfolds from a point of simplicity into a deep thread that sews together the best and worst of human nature.
Catching Fire burns across the screen with a fierce intent.
Frozen is an enchanting film that will surely lift spirits for the holiday season.
A vast improvement over the previous incarnation about the character's origin.
Out of the Furnace works as a bleak character piece, but fails as a drama and thriller.
American Hustle is a very well acted tale of con artists and their volatile relationships.
An unbridled tale of drug fueled sex and avarice, The Wolf of Wall Street moves like a breeze for its three hour runtime.
The Legend of Hercules is a total clunker.
The best compliment I can give this movie is that I look forward to the next one. Shadow Recruit is nothing special on its own, but does lay enough groundwork for future success.
I checked my brain out, and gasp, got some entertainment value from the film. The special effects, fight choreography, and production design are actually pretty good.
An all star cast of veteran actors can't save a tepid, sort of Cliff's Notes version of World War II heroics.
Pompeii is not going to have teenage girls swooning a la Titanic, but works as an action and disaster film.
Non-Stop can be picked apart like a buzzard on road kill. But if you want some breezy entertainment, then this film delivers in spades.
Stalingrad embraces technology to tell this bloody tale, but also paints a proud, nationalistic portrait of the terrible sacrifices made by civilians and soldiers.
Recommended for the action, special effects, and Eva Green. There's an attempt at a plot in there somewhere.
Divergent plods along at a snail pace. Everything unveils as expected without a whiff of surprise or nuance.
The Desolation of Smaug entertains, but the run time continues to be way too long.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The first act of Flight is as engrossing as any film I've seen this year. It's when the film starts pandering to Washington's performance that it loses steam.
Somewhere in there is an entertaining film, but The Lone ranger stretches your patience mightily.
The crisp, frenetic pacing turns dull and nonsensical as World War Z takes a detour for the silly in its third act.
Ang Lee has taken the most impossible of stories and given it life. Life of Pi is adventure on a grand scale; easily the most technically advanced film of 2012.
Zero Dark Thirty is a clinical, apolitical look at ten years of dogged determination. It is a thoughtful exploration of the elaborate puzzle put together to find Osama Bin Laden.

Peter Jackson triumphantly returns to Middle Earth with The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey. A folksy, beguiling adventure, we get to enjoy the splendor of the story and fantastic settings in a more whimsical experience.
Jack Reacher is a crisp actioner and mystery from writer/director Christopher McQuarrie.
Django Unchained is the wildest cinematic ride of the year.
Charming, but entirely predictable.
Old faithful still has the steam to get it done.
Parker ticks enough boxes as an action film to score a positive review.
The well has certainly dried up for the Die Hard franchise.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Dwayne Johnson has his best performance yet as a father fighting to save his son from a grave injustice.
The CGI effects and tepid intro will probably bore older viewers, but if you let yourself get into the story, then you're in for a decent time.
Drugs, trafficking, poverty, violence and love against the backdrop of a broken man. Redemption is Jason Statham's best film to date.
If you don't leave Oz with a smile on your face and bounce in your step, then you're a miserable grouch that surely needs a hug.
Olympus Has fallen packs a punch with its fair share of tired clichés. It's at once hokey and gripping, a pulp feature that certainly doesn't hold back.
Jonathan Pryce (The President) and Byung-hun Lee (Storm Shadow) steal the film from the muscled stars without firing a bullet.
Disconnect is an inspired parable of this age.
Oblivion is a sci-fi axiom colada.
The Numbers Station is a lean, tactile thriller that grabs you from the opening and keeps you aptly entertained.
Shane Black's Iron Man 3 is darker, funnier, more human, and with a few unexpected twists that will annoy some diehard fans while vastly entertaining the majority of audiences.
Set your phaser to awesome. Star Trek Into Darkness is a thrilling, joyride of a film that will have diehard trekkies and neophytes alike beaming.
Part Three is far from the glory of the first, but a reprieve from the second.
After Earth is an underwhelming exercise in science fiction that barely registers as entertainment.
You'll never look at Michael Cera the same way again.
Man of Steel is the prayer answered for those who wanted more punch in their Superman.
A lackluster script, poor direction, and a dialed-in lead performance from Steve Carell make this ensemble comedy a big disappointment. The lone highlight and saving grace is Jim Carrey.
Bridesmaids is an infectiously funny and bittersweet look at how life can change even the strongest of friendships.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
The Da Vinci Code succeeds as a popcorn film.
It is a shell of its predecessors, a technical exercise that is utterly devoid of substance.
A wonderfully imaginative film, filled with just the right amount of nostalgia and sentimentality to win over audiences of all ages.
Hollywood has long stereotyped Latino teens as violent, gangbanging thugs steeped in drugs and misogyny. Wassup Rockers is a welcome and different portrayal of Latino teenagers in America.
The cinematic rebirth of Superman could not have been put in abler hands. Director Bryan Singer has taken us soaring back into the sky.
Lady in the Water has some interesting moments, but fails because the story is so uninspiring. It simply does not achieve the greatness that it thinks it deserves.
Brilliant and poetic, a masterful and all-encompassing story of war.
A vividly crafted and cunning whodunit.
Casino Royale is the best Bond film in thirty years. Daniel Craig brings a toughness and edge long absent from the role.
300 explodes off the screen in IMAX. It is the only way to see this epic picture.
This film doesn't rely on cheap gags or fart jokes for its humor. Hot Fuzz is what you expect from a good satire, a lot of laughs, smart writing, and a cast talented enough to deliver the goods.
There is no great romance, no epic special effects, just a lot of terrible dialogue spoken by wooden actors in a film so CGI dependent; I felt like I was watching a video game.

Stylistically very different from anything we normally see in the United States. It's a lush film, bathed in an opulent darkness and dread. It has a Russian sensibility and embraces the character driven philosophy of European films.
Anthony Hopkins and Ryan Gosling are electrifying in Gregory Hoblit's otherwise mediocre thriller.
Finally, a breath of fresh air arrives in the stale summer of sequels.
A delightfully dark fairy tale!
Zack Snyder delivers Alan Moore's epic superhero saga to the silver screen with uncompromising vision and adoration.
I'm a bit on the fence with Knowing. It is well made, and bleak as hell, but just has a little too much going on for me to recommend it.
The bro-mance is in full bloom!
I think many young children will learn from this film without even realizing they're being taught something.
If all you want to is extreme car chases, explosions, and violence; then this is well worth the price of admission.
Do we even care about these characters enough to worry about their machinations?
Steve Martin reprises his role as the bumbling Inspector Clouseau in this hideous sequel to a boring remake.
A sci-fi thriller with a lot of science fiction and zero thrills.
This might be a stretch considering its two hour and forty-eight minute runtime, but you'll definitely get your money's worth.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In a lesser actor's hands, the powerful impact of the subject matter would not have been so ably delivered.
Ice Age 2 surpasses the original in every way. Fox Animation has a film to be extremely proud of.

A poorly paced and spectacularly disjointed rehash of Orwellian themes. It has a high production value and looks great, but suffers from a lack of narrative exposition that leads to sizable holes in the plot.
The story is a bit cliché, but it bristles with energy and positivism.

His latest film, Million Dollar Baby, propels Eastwood into that hallowed pantheon of the greatest directors. It is quite simply a film masterpiece, a heartbreaking tale of dreams won and lost, exquisitely stylized and expertly performed.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Easily the best basketball film I've seen in years.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
Thrillers are rarely so well conceived; Inside Man is a must-see.
Meirelles continues to distinguish himself as a director and notches another beautifully shot film.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
A major artistic achievement by Clooney and easily one of the best films of 2005.
Quote not available.
It entertains on all levels with a skillful blending of story and incredible visual effects.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
An absorbing film.
A subtle and context-driven approach to historical filmmaking.
I am a huge fan of Steve Martin and did like him as Clouseau. The film didn't live up to expectations, but his likeability did.
Gritty and disturbing.
It is a thinking man's comedy that is intelligent enough to look at all sides and make fun of everyone equally.
Quote not available.
A balls to the wall action film, and never for a second does it deviate.
It pains me to admit, and I may be distinctly in the minority here, but I really liked this film.
Lymelife is an interesting film that will have audiences drawing different conclusions.
A master stroke from a director in his prime. Inception is leagues above any live action film released in 2010.
Salt is a complete dud.
Stallone and crew deliver a hard-hitting, unrepentant action extravaganza.
The American is like a paperweight sitting on your head for two hours.
The Town is a thrilling actioner, but deeply personal and moving as well. Ben Affleck takes a giant leap forward as an artist with this film.
A rousing and heartwarming film, Diane Lane may get Disney the Best Actress Oscar.
A techno-fueled visual effects extravaganza,Tron Legacy is not quite the sequel I imagined.
While Jeff Bridges, Matt Damon, and Josh Brolin have their names above the marquee, the star of True Grit is thirteen year old Hailee Steinfeld.
If you can sit through an Uwe Boll movie, and be genuinely entertained; then run, don't walk, to see Season of the Witch.
The Green Hornet is a disjointed jumble of gag laughs, goofy stunts, and bizzare casting.
Likes or dislikes about The Eagle will be based on how you feel about Channing Tatum.
I pity the fool that takes this movie too seriously.
Hall Pass is hilarious, a return to form for the Farrelly Brothers.
There's never a doubt who will win in the aliens versus marines battle, but the fact that it's interesting from the first frame to the last is an achievement.
Zach Snyder has attended the Michael Bay school of filmmaking and graduated the top of the class.
Source Code deliciously bites off more than it can chew. It is a science fiction thriller foremost, but runs a wide gamut of human emotion.
This is Russell Brand light, and at least to me, fits the part.
While the sum of its parts do not add up, Saoirse Ronan shines brightly in this film.
Rio is a leap forward in quality and the finest work from Fox Animation.
Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is quite simply, wonderful; a brilliantly imagined story that will win old fans and new fans alike.
The Goblet of Fire is a more mature story and its young stars prove they have the acting skills to grow with their characters.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Spiderman 3 is best described as a Mexican soap opera with mind-blowing special effects.

Fantastic Four is terribly miscast. It's poorly written, visually uninteresting, and worst of all, boring. The film drags considerably. There are huge gaps without any action and it brings the pacing to an unbearable crawl.
Quote not available.
The age old quandary of human purpose, told with a modern twist, in screenwriter turned director George Nolfi's superb adaptation of Phillip K. Dick
A technically good effort, but more a Lifetime movie of the week substance wise.
An absolutely dreadful summer at the movies is rescued by the wizards at Pixar.
Watching a bewildered fat man try to reign in an uncontrollable party animal is pretty funny.
Humorous and touching, the first great movie of 2009.
Wolverine doesn't hold a candle to the X-Men trilogy and is a big step back for the franchise in general.
An epic adventure that deftly captures the spirit of the original series, while succeeding utterly in charting a new course.
Too many astonishingly obscure variables fall into place for this film to be believed.
Ninety minutes of pure perverse laughter
This celluloid abortion should be buried in a vault and shown to film students as an example of big Hollywood at its worst.
The film kicks you in the balls with awesomeness, but is smart enough not to turn back and keep kicking you until you forget you're being kicked.
A big-budget popcorn flick worthy of escapist fun
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Surrogates leaves you wanting more, but is entertaining for the short run time.
Predictable, but humorous.
A terrific satire of seventies blaxploitation classics
If you belong to a Jacob vs. Edward blog, or have a Twilight poster hanging over your bed, this is your movie.
Apart from the costume design, Amelia does not deserve any award buzz at all.
All style and no substance, Disney's A Christmas Carol is a yawn inducing retread of a tired fable.
An absurd comedy that borders on genius
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Like watching a Mexican soap opera with bad ass special effects.
Dripping with lush detail, spectacular battles, and superb acting performances, Red Cliff is a nuanced approach to combat rarely seen on screen in modern times
New Moon will undoubtedly be a blockbuster at the box office, but is really quite weak as a film.
Tim Burton's creative juices run dry in a decidedly boring and bland interpretation of Alice in Wonderland.
Director Antoine Fuqua scoops up the grime off the street and slimes it on the screen.
Rarely has a film lived up to its title so well!
It's a shame that Marvel saddled Iron Man 2 with the baggage of other films.
This latest rehash of Robin Hood is a prime example of what happens when big stars lose respect for the audience.
Even with a stellar cast and proven director, it's another banal exercise in video game adaptations.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Long live the king!

The Winter Soldier represents the evolution of Captain America into a more complex character. He still kicks major ass and can throw that shield like a death Frisbee, but does he have enough courage to ask out the hot babe that lives next door?
Captain Underpants is a potty humor masterpiece. It is meant for young children, but the adults will also be chuckling.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Other Woman brings up plot points that are never followed up. They simply disappear. This wouldn't be so glaring if they weren't so obvious.
Power Ranges surprisingly captures teen angst in an effective way. There is an edge to the characters that lead to unexpected moments.
CHiPs is hilarious. Dax Shepard and Michael Pena breathe life into the tired and stale buddy cop genre. I laughed myself silly from start to finish.
The Zookeeper's Wife is deeply emotional and visceral, but fails to reach the bar set by better examples of the genre. Jessica Chastain and Johan Heldenbergh deliver sublime performances.
Director Rupert Sanders has crafted a special effects wonder that will melt your eyeballs. If only the plot of Ghost in the Shell was on par with the technical achievement.
Gifted is a syrupy sweet melodrama that tugs on your heart like a violin.
Teen Titans: The Judas Contract is a fast paced, action packed entry in the DC Universe. The Justice League has serious competition.
Smurfs: The Lost Village has Smurfette facing an existential crisis. It will put a smile on youngsters faces, the parents not as much.
Charlie Hunnam shines in The Lost City of Z. Director James Gray delivers an intriguing and well shot biography of British explorer Percy Fawcett.
Free Fire has the characters crawling around like centipedes on the floor. It's a gimmick that wears thin fast.
The Promise is an imperfect, but extremely compelling historical drama about the Armenian Genocide. Oscar Isaac delivers a powerful performance.
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 bursts unto the screen like a pack of rainbow skittles. It's a roaring space adventure with humor and heart.
Director Danny Boyle recaptures lightning in a bottle. T2 Trainspotting is a vivid, frenetic sequel to the cult classic that made Ewan McGregor a star.
Emma Watson and Tom Hanks fall flat in The Circle, a dull and bloated exercise in technology's overreach.
A heartbreaking chronicle of a city under siege, Last Men in Aleppo exemplifies the power if cinema.
Alien: Covenant is a straight rehash of the same story. It's deja vu all over again.
Snatched is hilarious. It's a downright silly romp, but loaded with big laughs. The supporting cast adds a lot of unexpected humor.
A peculiar tale about a distinctly unlikeable fellow, Wakefield drags considerably.
Dead Men Tell No Tales is wildly uneven, but an improvement over the last installment. Johnny Depp goes to the well, but still rules the sea as Captain Jack Sparrow.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Baywatch has the expected eye candy, but is not clever and poorly made. Let the riptide drag you away from this one.
Wonder Woman is a winner, an immersive origin story with unexpected humor and epic action scenes. Gal Gadot proves she has the right stuff, every bit the feminist icon and hero fans deserve.
Draft Day is an amiable tale likely to win over non-critical audiences. It's basically a giant commercial for the National Football League.
Universal's Dark Universe franchise stumbles badly in its first installment. The Mummy is a bloated spectacle with a weak script and terrible performances.
Everything Jillian Bell touches is comedy gold.
47 Meters Down is a shark movie light on sharks. It is a weak entry in the genre with laughably foolish characters.
An entirely unpleasant film about appalling people, The Dinner is excruciating to sit through.
All Eyez on Me utterly lacks depth. It is a wikipedia biopic of Tupac Shakur.
Kong fans rejoice. Skull Island delivers the monster beat down exactly as promised.
Table 19 is a sweet and quirky comedy with a lot of heart. The ensemble cast shines in this tale of loners finding friendship.

Taissa Farmiga and John Travolta are excellent in Ti West's brilliant pulp western, In a Valley of Violence. The set-up is simple, really as straightforward as it gets; but the execution is damned entertaining.
Inferno is an entirely illogical thriller filled with historical babble and endless chases. The third time is certainly not the charm for Director Ron Howard and Tom Hanks.
Doctor Strange will obliterate your expectations. It is an enormously entertaining film; a rousing cinematic adventure loaded with stunning visual effects.
Hacksaw Ridge is a parable of how values can keep you strong in the worst of places. Mel Gibson returns to directing greatness. Andrew Garfield will be a strong contender for the Best Actor Oscar.
Bleed For This is an inspirational knockout. Miles Teller is proving to be a supremely versatile actor.
Newt Scamander doesn't have the charm or gravitas of Harry Potter, but Fantastic Beasts still proves to be an enthralling expereince.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Bad Santa 2 is as gloriously raunchy as the original, you will laugh yourself into the ground.
Allied is the date movie to see this Thanksgiving. It's a thematically dark story and a solid romance. Marion Cotillard and Brad Pitt are a dynamic duo.
Natalie Portman is stunning as Jacqueline Kennedy in the aftermath of her husband's assassination. Chilean Director Pablo Larrain crafts a sublimely artistic and intimate portrayal of her struggle.
Office Christmas Party has just enough laughs to nudge a positive recommendation. Jillian Bell is hilarious. She steals the show from the all-star cast of comedy veterans.
Lucasfilm has outdone themselves. They've delivered a thrilling installment that embodies the best of Star Wars. Rogue One surpasses every expectation.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Beauty and the Beast is a lavish spectacle. The major drawback is the total lack of surprise. The film is well made, but plays out exactly as expected.
La La Land is a beautiful, inspired film. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone will leave you with a bounce in your step and love in your hearts.

Three women of color transcended the boundaries of their time. They rose above a segregated, sexist society to show that intellect is color blind and gender neutral. Hidden Figures is a long overdue story.
James McAvoy is a one man show here. He gives a psychopathic tour de force performance. Split is M. Night Shyamalan's best film in fifteen years.
Waif thin, scantily clad girls and chiseled dudes rain destruction on hapless baddies. xXx: Return of Xander Cage is an eye-candy action flick, pure and simple.
Justice League Dark is worthy of the R-rating. It's markedly violent and truly dwells in the mystical realm, but is burdened by an overly intricate plot with multiple characters.
McConaughey's latest is no treasure.
Science fiction meets young adult romance in the mostly forgettable The Space Between Us. The film has an interesting premise, but suffers from poor direction and a meandering script.
Director Chris McKay takes the Dark Knight on a riotous, heartfelt new adventure. The LEGO Batman Movie is hilarious. Adults and children alike are going to be rolling in the aisles.
Fifty Shades Darker is not a comedy. Or at least I think it's not supposed to be funny. The sequel to Fifty Shades of Grey is borderline farcical.
Zhang Yimou's The Great Wall is a sleek monster film that befits the artistry of its director. It's action packed, beautifully shot, and much more humorous than expected.
Logan is a dark and thrilling finale for Wolverine. Director James Mangold brings stark realism to the comic genre.

Get Out is an absolutely brilliant and original horror film. Imagine a devilishly twisted update of Guess Who's Coming to Dinner. Get Out is scary, laugh out loud funny, and an inspired satire of interracial relationships.
Passengers starts off with an interesting premise. Instead of capitalizing on its strong start, it peters away into science-fiction and romance convention.
Ben Affleck's numbers just don't add up in The Accountant.
Okja is a thoughtful, visceral satire of the corporate meat industry. Director Bong Joon-ho once again challenges convention with brilliance.
Baby Driver is a turbo-charged action classic.
The God of Thunder throws more punchlines than punches in Marvel's latest.
A sincere, harrowing journey through post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), and the havoc it wreaks on families.
A Bad Moms Christmas has an entirely predictable storyline, but the laughs are consistent throughout. A few are real gems that will have you rolling.
Kenneth Branagh's lavish remake is a worthy adaptation of Agatha Christie's most famous novel.
The Justice League is not without fault, but the good outweighs the bad by a mile. The characters form a solid foundation for future greatness.
Roman J. Israel, Esq. is a fascinating character study that ultimately fails as a cohesive film.
Margot Robbie and Allison Janney deliver their career best performances
The Shape of Water is a good effort from Guillermo Del Toro. It's not on par with his best work, but that's a pretty high standard. He nailed the casting of Sally Hawkins.
Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is very funny. The humor alone warrants viewing. The cast, both young and old, are solid in their performances.
Star Wars fans, your sky high expectations are rewarded. Rian Johnson takes the fabled lore from a galaxy far away into uncharted territory. He will have you spellbound.
Matt Damon and Alexander Payne go small with mixed results.
Geostorm is quite silly and illogical with a barrage of CGI effects. 4DX is the only way to see this film. It turns the experience into a theme park ride.
David Ayer doesn't stray far from his wheelhouse, even with the fantasy aspects. Bright can be genuinely summed up as End of Watch with magical creatures. That's not a negative.
Hostiles is a gripping, violent western that unfortunately neglects its Cheyenne characters.
The Death Cure is an action-packed and somber conclusion to The Maze Runner. The final installment of the popular young adult novels scales upwards on all fronts.
Gotham By Gaslight is a dark tale that ranks among the best of the DC Animated Universe. Fans of the classic comic will love this film.
Peter Rabbit is a rousing bunny adventure for all ages. Beatrix Potter's classic hero gets hip and hilarious for modern times.
Black Panther is a comic masterpiece that transcends the genre. Michael B. Jordan is fantastic as Eric Killmonger, the best villain yet from Marvel Studios.
The 15:17 to Paris is a film about heroism portrayed by the actual heroes. Unfortunately, Clint Eastwood's retelling of their story falls woefully flat.
Red Sparrow runs long, but captivates with a strong lead performance and shocking violence. It is easily the most graphic film we've seen from Jennifer Lawrence.
Annihilation is a slow crawl creep show with jolts good enough to send your popcorn airborne.
Death Wish is no different than a standard, bloody action flick. Some parts are devastating, others funny, but the overall film lacks the punch of the original.
A Wrinkle in Time is a sappy melodrama, devoid of mystery or wonder. Director Ava DuVernay beats positivity in with a sledgehammer.
Gringo will certainly tickle your funny bone. The outrageous characters more than make up for the bewildering plot
Jessica Chastain dazzles as Molly Bloom. Aaron Sorkin was wise to cast her in his directorial debut.
Transformers: The Last Knight is a towering special effects achievement with a befuddling plot. Fans of the 1986 animated film will be on board for this ride.
Love conquers all in Breathe, a warm and uplifting true story from motion capture legend Andy Serkis.
Only the Brave is a fitting tribute to the men who fought the Yarnell Hill Fire. It is a tale of brotherhood, loyalty, and valor under the most extreme duress.
War for the Planet of the Apes is a deeply emotional, riveting film that pushes the boundaries of motion capture performance.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Spider-Man: Homecoming is a funny, heartfelt, coming of age story that defly captures the awkwardness of being a teenager.
Trey Parker steals the film as supervillain Balthazar Bratt. He will dance battle you into liking Despicable Me 3.
Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets is stunning visually. It never reaches the point of rousing sci-fi adventure, but makes an all out effort to get there.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Dunkirk is a gripping story of survival told through cutting edge camera work and bare bones storytelling. Christopher Nolan has delivered a classic war film.
Cold War espionage thriller meets eighties new wave dance party in Atomic Blonde.
Kathryn Bigelow and screenwriter Mark Boal return to greatness with Detroit.
The Dark Tower is a quick draw take on a very complex story. It is a moderately successful adaptation.
Logan Lucky is a hillbilly heist caper brimming with good natured humor.
Taylor Sheridan has an auspicious directorial debut with the riveting Wind River.
Ingrid Goes West is a fairly humorous but uneven take on social media obsession. It needed to dig deeper regarding the mental health aspects of the story.
The Snowman is poorly made, an utter waste of a talented cast, and mind-numbing to sit through.
Australian actress Danielle Macdonald shines as an overweight girl aspiring to be a rapper.
The terror that crept up your spine as a kid hiding from the closet monster is here in bloody spades.
There's a lot to like and dislike here. The filmmaking aspects and actresses are superb. Where Aronofsky goes off the rails is the substance, a long runtime, and avalanche of absurdity.
American Assassin is a no holds barred, ass-kicking action flick. It fires on all cylinders from the gut-wrenching start. Dylan O'Brien is vengeance and ferocity personified.
Oxfords, not brogues meets Tequila and Whiskey in this rousing sequel. Director/writer Matthew Vaughn recaptures the humor and over the top action that made the original such a hit.
The LEGO Ninjago Movie is a hyper visual adventure loaded with humor and warmth. Kids will be dazzled by the frenetic animation, while enjoying a lot of laughs with the adults.
Tom Cruise and Doug Liman are back with another winner. American Made is a breezy, highly entertaining story of arms and drug trafficking in the early eighties.
Idris Elba and Kate Winslet sell the characters and situation fully, establishing a deep relationship that will enthrall audiences.
Battle of the Sexes is a sublime achievement, the textbook definition of comedy and drama. Fox Searchlight has a behemoth contender come award season.
Blade Runner 2049 is a towering sequel to the science fiction classic. It is visually spellbinding, a dark odyssey that flirts with greatness.
Marshall is an absolutely riveting film. It is a snapshot of Jim Crow America, where racism and segregation permeated every facet of life.
The Foreigner is a smart, engaging action thriller. It delivers exactly as promised, Jackie Chan as you've never seen him.
Batman and Harley Quinn eeks out a recommendation for the humor.
Park Chan-wook's The Handmaiden is a chef-d'oeuvre of intrigue and erotica. It is a sumptuously artistic tale, exquisitely shot, that will leave you breathless.
Arrival is unlike any science fiction film you have seen. It builds like a slow boil into a deeply cerebral, emotionally expansive journey.
The Girl on the Train is a dark, sensual ride between madness and murder. Emily Blunt and her female co-stars are outstanding here.
Beautifully directed by Kenneth Branagh, every fame sparkles with an opulent vibrancy that perfectly captures the faerie tale element.
Another nonsensical young adult film that makes me root for the evil dystopian society against the plucky heroine.
A crude farce based on racial stereotypes, homophobia, and prison rape. Get Hard is incredibly stupid and juvenile...but I laughed, I laughed enough to recommend it.
Furious 7 is basically a live action version of Grand Theft Auto, with a touching tribute to its fallen star - Paul Walker.
The Avengers return in an epic adventure with a little romance and tragedy to keep the spectacle grounded.
Painfully unfunny and offensive. Sofia Vergara's one trick pony of playing the spicy Latina falls flatter than the mild sauce at Taco Bell.
Mad Max: Fury Road is a masterpiece of cinema, a full throttle symphony of mayhem and exhilaration that will blow audiences out of their chairs.
Brad Bird's sci-fi adventure starts off brilliantly as a mystery, then devolves into a series of chases. It's not quite a jetpack ride, but entertaining enough to recommend.
The Rock delivers big, dumb disaster fun. San Andreas asks you to check your brain at the door, sit back, and enjoy CGI buildings toppling like Legos
The same celebrity worshipping narcissism and sexual objectification that made the TV series a hit for HBO.
If your only reason for watching this film is to see CGI dinosaurs eat people, then you'll get your money's worth. The characters offer their innards like hors d'oeuvres.
The beautiful people are the sleight of hand that will keep you entertained.

'Inside Out' is a sad, emotionally loaded film that drains any initial exuberance like a faucet. Note to Pixar and Disney, please go back to making films that are more fun than not. I don't want to be bummed out watching a kid's film.
'Terminator Genisys' is not remotely on par with the greatness of the first two, but is a definite improvement over the last installment.
'Minions' swings wildly from inventive and hilarious, to oddly dark and boring in stretches.
'Ant-Man starts weak, but finishes strong. What starts as a drizzle becomes a hurricane of action and special effects as 'Ant-Man' kicks into high gear during its second half.
The powerhouse performance of star Jake Gyllenhaal lifts the boxing drama 'Southpaw' to a raw, emotional high.
Despite the shortcomings of the plot, 'Rogue Nation' is a summer blockbuster that delivers the popcorn movie goods.
It's mind boggling how so many good parts could be assembled into such a bad movie, the 'Fantastic Four' reboot is appalling.

The Birth of a Nation is a brutal, unflinching look at slavery. In a time when race relations have become the hot button subject in an election year, this film is a timely reminder of a deplorable shared history.
A comedic take on the CIA's infamous MK Ultra program could have been great, but American Ultra falls woefully short. This stoner assassin bores.
The nightmare scenario depicted in 'No Escape' is so terrifying, even the most skeptical viewer will be enthralled.
'The Transporter Refueled' has a ludicrous and wafer thin plot, but fans of the franchise will enjoy it; an action packed guilty pleasure.
'The Visit' is another woeful outing from M. Night Shyamalan. It is a gimmicky, parlor trick film with a blatantly obvious twist ending.
'Ted 2' may not be as good as the original, but it still entertains enough to warrant a trip to the theater.
McFarland, USA quickly elevates above convention into a drama that will pull your heartstrings. It is a stunningly well crafted and inspirational film.
Kingsman: The Secret Service takes Bond's vodka martini and adds a shot of adrenaline to the mix.
Beyond Project Almanac's shaky concept, the bouncing and skewed angle camerawork is an entirely unpleasant experience.

Watching The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is like the buffet at Golden Corral. There's a lot of choices, you over stuff your plate, and in the end, you ate too much. But you still feel like you got your money's worth.
Warner Brothers and Director Gareth Edwards deserves a golf clap. They have taken a franchise that has been laughable for decades and made it into something audiences will flock to see.
Strap yourself in kids, because this is why you go to summer movies. Director Bryan Singer has absolutely nailed Days of Future Past.
Sleeping Beauty reloaded. Maleficent is darker than expected and an incredible visual experience.
The Matrix Revolutions meets Groundhog Day, Edge of Tomorrow is Tom Cruise's most entertaining film in years.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Cinema is rarely so menacing and provocative. The Rover is that desired bit of sour in a summer full of cinematic fluff.
Transformium, wow! Meant to be funny, but is really a whole lot of stupid.
Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is the new pinnacle of a franchise that has endured for over four decades. Director Matt Reeves delivers a stunning film, deeply emotional and character driven.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Hercules is a solid popcorn film and a better than average entry this summer.

There's lots of action, incredible 3D, all the bells and whistles audiences expect from a tentpole film. But it's the brilliant humor that will help Guardians undoubtedly be one of the biggest hits of the year.
Megan Fox, who plays the plucky reporter - April O' Neil, is front and center when it comes to screen time here. Her dull performance was not the banner to hang this movie's success on.
The Giver may satisfy the legions that have read the book, but is a rather predictable, mediocre film.
Sin City: A Dame to Kill For is a known commodity that is pretty much on par with the original. At the very least, seeing the smoldering Eva Greene melt the screen is worth the price of admission.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Maze Runner is a superior entry in Hollywood's onslaught of adolescents versus future dystopia films. It's interesting, well acted, well directed, and delivers a highly original outcome.
A Walk Among the Tombstones is a bit too methodical in the delivery, but is mysterious enough to hold your attention throughout.

The Equalizer is a serious action film led by Hollywood's best leading actor. Director Antoine Fuqua spends a significant amount of screen time delving into the psyche and character of a truly admirable protagonist.
Gone Girl is a devilish mystery and star-making performance for Rosamund Pike.
Whiplash is a must see and will contend for the best film of 2014. Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons deliver magnetic performances.
Nightcrawler is a thrilling, dark journey into the mind of a sociopath and the cutthroat nature of success at all costs. It taps into that lurid vein of morbid fascination.

Christopher Nolan's Interstellar is desperately reaching for Stanley Kubrick 2001 greatness and achieving Robert Zemeckis mediocrity in Contact. It's no small bit of irony that both films star Matthew McConaughey and his southern drawl.
Mockingjay Part 1 is a hideously boring, bleak film. They've taken thirty minutes of plot, then stretched it out like taffy into an insufferable two hours.
The story of Alan Turing, and his immeasurable contribution to modern society, is superbly adapted for the screen in The Imitation Game.
Diehard fans will embrace this film, I'm finally done with the CGI battles and melodrama of Middle Earth.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Blackhat is a plodding, visually murky snoozer whose plot is completely illogical.
Strange Magic is not remotely in the same class as Frozen or Maleficent, but does deliver a pop medley fueled lesson on the meaning of true love.
A textbook for brilliant ensemble acting, Johnny Depp is ruthless, calculating, and magnetic in 'Black Mass'.
Tobey Maguire gives a career best performance as the brilliant, but erratic chess champion Bobby Fischer in 'Pawn Sacrifice'.
'The Man from U.N.C.L.E' is an ultra-stylish throwback to the spy genre of the sixties and the perfect way to cap off summer.
In a world filled with distrust, 'Bridge of Spies' portrays the virtue of principle in a masterful film from Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks.
The heroes in a half shell finally get a worthy movie with Out of the Shadows. It captures the spirit of the 80's cartoon and comic books.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Don't believe the haters. Fans of the game and fantasy genre will definitely like Warcraft. It is an entertaining and immersive epic.
Finding Dory is an incredibly imaginative sequel with just the right amount of humor and heart.
The Neon Demon is both enthralling and disgusting, with Nicolas Winding Refn turning in one of the most visceral film experiences of the year.
Free State of Jones is a gritty, well purposed Civil War drama. The approach is heavy handed and preachy, but the film has a mountain of substance to deliver.
'The Martian' is a rousing, surprisingly funny, and touching space adventure. Ridley Scott has delivered his best film since 'Gladiator'.
Ghostbusters isn't remotely on par with the original, but by no means terrible. Chris Hemsworth steals the film completely.
Star Trek Beyond is basically fast and furious in space. It will entertain the majority, but leave Trekkies nostalgic. Alas, Gene Roddenberry's vision of Star Trek is no more.
It is not a worthy reflection of an iconic story.

Jason Bourne is a swift actioner that never lets up for a second. Whatever political statements it attempts to make is negligible under the action onslaught. Matt Damon hasn't forgotten how to beat bad guys to a pulp.
Suicide Squad never tries to be anything more than the cool whip on top of the sundae. It's a kicks and giggles take on the DC universe, vastly more entertaining than Batman v Superman.
Alice Through the Looking Glass proves to be a yawn-inducing sequel that drags like a rake through sand.
Disney's update of Pete's Dragon isn't nearly as whimsical as the original, but stands on its own with heart and meaning.
Paramount's remake of Ben-Hur stands on its own as a decent film. Timur Bekmambetov delivers a solidly entertaining, well-shot, biblical epic. Charlton Heston is not spinning in his grave.
Morgan is a very dumb movie about smart people. Director Luke Scott's forgettable sci-fi thriller fails to achieve the highs of last year's Ex-Machina.
The Light Between Oceans is a painfully slow and obvious melodrama. I felt every second of its two hour and twelve minute runtime.
Clint Eastwood's adaptation of the "Miracle on the Hudson" isn't quite as riveting as hoped. Sully is fairly acted by the players, but runs short with a few scenes that come off as contrived.
Renee Zellweger's third outing as Helen Fielding's irrepressibly charming and daft Londoner is a winner. Bridget Jones's Baby is the best date movie of 2016 so far.
Oliver Stone views Edward Snowden as a hero and depicts him as such. It is a decidedly unbalanced approach.
Fantastic cast chemistry and the raw, leading-man star power of Denzel Washington provides a mighty lift when needed.
Director Peter Berg captures hell with technical precision in Deepwater Horizon, reminding us of the heavy price paid in blood and tears.
Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children is a wildly imaginative, but uneven film. Some parts are fantastically dark, then it loses steam in stretches.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Pierce Brosnan is a more than capable actor in any role. He saves I.T. from being altogether rote.
Masterminds doesn't live up to its comedy pedigree. The all-star cast of comedy veterans needed a stronger script to keep the laughs coming.
Laika Studios are back in superb form with Kubo and the Two Strings, an eye-popping visual delight.
Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising is a sloppily crafted, dismal sequel. It has a few humorous moments, but not enough to make up for the terrible execution.
The Purge: Election Year is a gruesomely violent, wall-to-wall action horror flick that is owned by Frank Grillo. It's a B-movie with a budget that smartly embraces the pulp.
X-Men: Apocalypse doesn't quite reach the lofty heights of the genre's best, but is a solidly entertaining film. Evan Peters steals the show again as Quicksilver.
'The Last Witch Hunter' has a promising occult plot and great visual effects, but is derailed by poor acting and disjointed action scenes.
Bradley Cooper is not believable as a Michelin starred chef in 'Burnt'. Send this dish back to the kitchen.
'Spectre' is a nod to the classic scenes, characters, and imagery from Bond lore. It is formulaic, but spectacular nonetheless.
'The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2' is heavy on the melodrama, but it picks up speed and delivers an ending that packs a wallop.
'Creed' is a winner and a sublime achievement that all audiences are going to love.
Money Monster is a lean thriller. It points a damning finger at the financial tycoons and media apparatus that enable billion dollar swindles.
'The Big Short' is a damning indictment of Wall Street. Director Adam McKay delivers a laymen's guide to understanding how sub-prime mortgage lending led to a devastating global recession.

'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' easily lives up to its mammoth hype, but it's not flawless, nor a better film than the original trilogy. It is a non-stop action film with a shotgun pace, like plugging the cotton candy machine directly into your face.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Quentin Tarantino's unrequited love for 60s era spaghetti westerns is again on display in 'The Hateful Eight'. It is a gruesomely violent, garrulous, and protracted homage to a style of filmmaking the director fervently adores.
'The Finest Hours' is a rousing, old-fashioned tale of remarkable heroism and grit.
'Hail, Caesar!' has no lack of star power, but falls decidedly flat in insufferably dull stretches. The Coen Brothers have a rare miss with their Hollywood golden age satire.
'Gods of Egypt' is a poorly acted CGI spectacle that plays like a video game. Diversity couldn't save this silly mess.

Dirty Grandpa is a barrel of laughs, just the bottom of the barrel. It is spectacularly perverse, sophomoric, and sexist; with no redeeming social qualities whatsoever. But it's funny, outrageously funny, basking in unrepentantly low brow humor.
Disney's 'Zootopia' is wildly adventurous and knockdown funny, arguably the best film of 2016 so far.
Captain America v Iron Man succeeds where Batman v Superman utterly failed. Civil War is Marvel's greatest action film so far.
Key & Peele delve into uncharted cat humor territory in 'Keanu'. The film swings from riotously funny to oddly dull in stretches, though it helps that the kitten is disgustingly cute.

'London Has Fallen' is an absurd, bloody action romp that plays like a B-movie. The film does have entertainment value. Gerard Butler is a one-man killing machine; cutting down hordes of terrorists while zinging one-liners.
Disney's 'The Jungle Book' is an incredible cinematic experience that will dazzle children and adults.
Hardcore Henry is seen from the first person perspective, an interesting gimmick if the experience wasn't so jarring or if the plot made sense at all.
Kevin Costner gets downright nasty in Criminal, a quasi sci-fi action thriller with a big name cast and straight-to-video execution.

'Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice' is a cluttered, gloomy spectacle that does not live up to the three year wait. The choices made and direction by Zack Snyder have resulted in a shaky foundation for the Justice League.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: 'Midnight Special' is a well-crafted science fiction mystery that doesn't quite pay off.
'The Brothers Grimsby' is a raunchy, hilarious romp that will have you falling out of your seat laughing.

10 Cloverfield Lane is a taut psychological thriller with superb performances from Mary Elizabeth Winstead and John Goodman. The measured reveal of the mysterious plot establishes a palpable tension throughout.
Richard Linklater returns to his Dazed and Confused form with another lighthearted, supremely enjoyable tale of youth - Everybody Wants Some. This eighties party is a blast.
[Yun Jung-hee's] quiet gestures, gentle gaze and tender pose transform themselves into stanzas as they rhyme with Lee's cinema.
Weaves a web of ideas and connections.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Fassbinder is not interested in offering simple solutions to his character's woes or depicting their decision making as consistent. The impact of Fear Eats the Soul lies in the way all of the characters are shown to be fallible and flawed.
movie_title: Angst Essen Seele auf (Ali: Fear Eats the Soul) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Though not entirely naff, this teen film's casting of Vanessa Hudgens is clearly an attempt to get High School Musical fans on board, but overall this is a charming effort.
Wow special effects and a top supporting cast can't override the numbing length of this best-of disaster movie blockbuster.
Although an improvement on Southland Tales, Richard 'Donnie Darko' Kelly's cryptic moody thriller has a far-fetched premise that is not helped by a script filled with holes.
This tense doco covers many disturbing issues at the same time capturing incredible images at great personal risk.
A haunting meditation on ageing, the purpose of art, and the nature of mortality.
An entertaining thrill ride but not much more.
Trumping the first sequel, and approaching the quality of the original, High School Musical 3: Senior Year is a truly winning reprise.
Despite its genuinely seductive veneer, American Teen doesn't have anything to say about the adolescent condition that American Graffiti didn't already cover off in 1973.
Forstmann, who has nursed this film toward a difficult conception, has delivered a production that works well as a human emotion mystery.
There is genuine sparkle in the voice work and more than a few jokes that really do hit the sweet spot.
Diesel's bassoon-voiced, low-watt charisma seems best placed in this franchise, and there is an undeniable spark with his foil Walker, who's all white teeth and Californian tan.
Finds a host of familiar faces performing below their best on a time-warp trip.

A filmmaker who is always cerebral and occasionally very soulful, Jarmusch -- fascinating even at his most tepid -- could do better to have a lot more red blood flowing through his recent work and a little less ice water.
Driven by a fine script and top performances, this powerfully affecting drama reveals an astonishing untold Australian war story.
Jake The Man makes for pure documentary gold, with his salty turns of phrase, busted heart, and that tiny sliver of hope which he clings to like a boa constrictor even in his darkest hours.
movie_title: The Resurrection of Jake The Snake Roberts (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Sure, it's flamboyant and saccharine, but with all the cast in top form, this is also infectious, uplifting, and occasionally stirring stuff.
While it's largely lightweight, this delightful comedy is easily carried by the undiminished star power of Catherine Deneuve and Gerard Depardieu.
An esoteric, sometimes stubbornly paced slice-of-life that recalls a middle-aged Before Sunset, Certified Copy is an almost-love story that ultimately drifts between moments of magnetism and tedium.

Debut director Sean Byrne has carved out a flick to stand beside Brian De Palma's high school horror classic Carrie, such is the beauty and brutality of his execution. It's the best entry to the Aussie horror canon since Wolf Creek.
Those expecting rollicking thrills may be disappointed but this succeeds as a finely acted slow-burning espionage film.
Clever, cutting and debateable, The Social Network should inspire discussion -- most likely played out on Facebook -- for months to come.
Featuring a highly impressive ensemble cast, this smart and stylish thriller is hugely entertaining.
In the darkened anonymity of the theatre, you'll be enjoying every sappy twist along the way.
Beautifully realised and touching on serious issues, this moving film is propelled by big laughs and an even bigger heart.
The Killer Inside Me ultimately registers as a startling curio that you may gasp at now but forget later.
Elevated by first-rate acting and brilliantly choreographed, this film proves that simple stories can often be the most absorbing.
Make a note of the names Delépine and de Kervern. That way you can avoid them in future.
No great surprises in the early segments, but the intensity grows as the shadows of age and illness fall. Even the blokes will be sniffling into their popcorn.
As the practically somnambulist Doug, Lankenau has a ramshackle charm that recalls Mark Ruffalo, while Dunn does wonders with a part that has to be created mainly in reaction shots.
A film that shrugs off its small budget to present a meditation on survival and suffering.
Definitely more enjoyable when you break it down into bits and pieces in your head afterwards.
An unexpected and individual take on sin and the devil by a director who - shock horror - actually has something to say.
It seems just as fresh, spry and quirky now as it did back then.

With Hinako Sugiura's historical manga 'Sarusuberi' as his inspiration, director Keiichi Hara and screenwriter Miho Maruo have pared down the episodic source material to create a work that is truly magical: must-see storytelling at its finest.
Preceding From Dusk Till Dawn by two years, Lurking Fear (1994) performs a similar trick... only it does it on a budget and, you won't be surprised to hear, not nearly as well.
A movie you'll muse upon for new shades of meaning.
Though he directs the film more or less straight as a prison/interrogation drama, Stewart's satirical edge cuts nicely.
The premise is so simple and the storytelling so uncluttered that it cannot fail to lodge in your mind.
If you go expecting the usual gangster flick violence, you might come out feeling short-changed but, if you let the film get to you, this is an absorbing contribution to a central American obsession.
There are a few problems with the film, not least the ending (no spoilers), but it has the pizazz and all the elements that you would expect from a film like this.
If this film were an apprentice it would have to serve several more years before being allowed master status.
A crazy, crackling, wild ride.
A watchable and well-acted crime caper.
Few directors today can get so much weight and psychological depth into such mesmerizing visuals.
Though not perfect, Black Sea is a tense piece of pressure cooker entertainment.
Boychoir is nice to look at and great to listen to,but with a bit more work, it could have really hit the highnotes.
Worth a look? Rather.
This is a rambling, slightly shambolic, but beautifully messed up film.
There are some glorious moments of violence and the usual hail of bullets when the action starts, but the heart of the film is in the journey.
Mulligan displays reserves of fortitude to add to her more familiar winsomeness, while Vinterberg relishes the challenge of keeping all this timeless and contemporary.
One can only relish the chance to see a player of McKellen's skill in a dramatic role, and he is reason enough to see the film.
Possibly the film sounds grim when described flatly, but it is haunting and brilliantly acted and directed, and there are grace notes of heroism in there as well as unwarranted suffering.
The film has good elements and decent performances, but just as the characters seem to mull over missed opportunities, we are left to feel the same way about the film.
With Foxcatcher, Bennett Miller has made an unsettling but memorable piece of cinema.
The film itself is playful and quite fun.
The film gets even more sentimental as it strains not to be so.
The characterisations are only half-deep, and some of the coincidences almost ridiculous, but the twists and turns are the main game.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Coppola clearly has the filmmaking gene. Further, by collaborating with James Franco (on whose stories the film is loosely based), she injects much-needed adult counterpoint. The casting is mostly good.
This is profundity with a light touch. The film itself is funny, sweet and affecting in just the right kind of way.

There's an occasional brief, fierce laugh born out of the absurdity of the situations. At other points, the women provide genuine insight into relationships. Thank god for their realism and sanity. Still, this feels like a short bloated into a feature.
movie_title: A Complete History of My Sexual Failures (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film as a whole is characterised by its sweeping grasp of history, and is movingly couched in a powerful human story.
We see what an actor's actor Pacino can be: he's careful and watchful; respectful of other actors' timing; and says his lines perfectly, resisting all temptation to grandstand.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Winding Refn has created a gripping tale of the institutionalised madness of this violent criminal who relishes in his new found alter ego.
A far more upbeat film from usually gritty director Ken Loach, which uses soccer star Eric Cantona in effectively comedic ways.
In Broken Embraces, his vibrant new mixed genre thriller, he is out to entertain and intrigue. Almodovar also wants to tell us something about desire and his love of cinema.
A bad ending doesn't detract too much from the great cast, plentiful blood and guts effects and rollicking pace.

It's a conventional enough story, but Audiard invests it with a kind of metaphysical dimension. In tone and style, it is a little reminiscent of the fine recent Italian mafia film Gomorrah and, like that film, will be talked about for many years to come.
Go and see this moving and humane film.
Driven by natural performances, this perfectly reflects the ups and downs of everyday life with laughs and warmth.
Modest and leisurely, albeit exhaustive and insightful, this would have been even better with extended music sequences.
movie_title: George Harrison: Living In The Material World (2011)

movie_review_blurb: More akin to a commentary than a "film", Jafar Panahi proves an engaging presence and crucial political voice.
Perhaps more suited to television, the film nevertheless will please classical music fans and Haydn is certainly owed a renewed assessment and a current audience.
This doesn't quite hit the grand heights of recent Pixar creations and overdoes its Scottishness, but it's beautifully crafted and packed with humour and heart.
An absorbing and complex character drama, but one that's difficult to connect to at times.
The narrative is slight, but this beguiling film finds its strength in the deftly observed relationships and feelings of the key players.
A languid, poetic but emotionally powerful work, which reaffirms Cate Shortland's talent behind the camera and announces a promising new talent in its lead actress.

A strong and well observed fifties period piece, Kill Your Darlings brilliantly captures both the heady sense of privilege, and the decadent whiff of The Beat Generation's brief and blazing demimonde.
Thought provoking and enjoyable.
In Baker, we have a director who can make ordinary, quirky and disorganised lives seem colourful, compelling and most of all, humanistic.
Sometimes the simplest ideas are the best, and this lovely little film from Lebanon is a perfect example.
In the confines of the theatre, this might have proved very effective, but it's less so here.
...contains characteristic moments of great beauty...
...a strange ride, but a haunting little film.
First time director, and co-writer, Vahid Jalilvand, shows early maturity in the handling of the strong cast, and in the emotional palette of the film.
...a convincing and substantial piece of cinema..
...it just doesn't ring true.
This is a great film by an important lone voice.
...impressive...
In time, we may look back on Rosalie Blum as this year's Amelie.
explores yet another facet of a fascinating creative person.
...one last tilt at the racial antagonism that is still the stain on the whole American project.
So, it is a formula. Who cares, when you have these two in full flow?
The film is pretty long and frankly it feels it, partly because it spends too much time padding out unnecessary individual backstories.
...[for] a good jolt and moderate comedy-gore, this is well worth catching.
...the focus is rightly on the two leads and fans of theirs won't want to miss the chance to see them one more time.
...there are moments of simple truthfulness.
richly-detailed British costume drama
...fluently-directed and charmingly-realised French film.
movie_title: Just to Be Sure (Ôtez-moi d'un doute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ...another haunting masterwork.
...some genuinely hilarious set ups and a nice mixture of farce and other styles of comedy.
...moves you profoundly.
it all comes off with the rising and emotional sense of achievement that was so heart-warming in the original
movie_title: As It Is In Heaven 2: Heaven On Earth (2016)

movie_review_blurb: ...a satisfyingly sweet confection which will find, and please, its audience.
Some of the scenes are eye-popping...

How they did it, and what it cost is the real story. I'm glad it's told as well as it is.
Polanski's master touch, his attention to framing, lighting, to every detail, and his wicked visual witticisms make it a joy for any film lover. Welcome back, Roman.

movie_review_blurb: Director Doug Liman has done a pretty good job maintaining the pace and tension in this film, though I could have done with a little less hand-held camera. Penn is superb, and Watts is pretty credible.

An explosive and timely film.

It's a refreshing, vastly entertaining film.

Hawkins is irresistible as O'Grady, and Miranda Richardson gives a fine turn as Barbara Castle with a ginger perm. But why are British working-class stories so often presented so rosily in cinema? Oh well. Enjoyable anyway.

I can't say I've warmed much to Bruce Willis films before now. I went to see RED with no expectations, and came out thoroughly cheered.

I warn you, this film is long. Two hours and forty minutes worth. Dance gives it its constant pulse, while it builds, slowly. It will reward your patience, it may even make new converts to dance as an art form.

movie_review_blurb: Narcissistic nonsense, styled within an inch of its life in the manner of food, fashion and travel magazines.

movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, it's the writing, and Ferrell's and Wahlberg's performances which make this film.

This is a witty and insightful film. Lisa Cholodenko has a talent for observational comedy; comedies which capture the zeitgeist, usually achieved by throwing together people with two different sets of expectations.
Unlike conventional thrillers, this film does not restore a moral order to the universe. Rather, it questions it. It must be seen.
Demonstrates the unusual power of thoughtful, subjective filmmaking.

movie_review_blurb: It is illuminating, if unedifying, viewing.

The Ritual is shot so beautifully it helps mitigate that uneasiness.

All the more disappointing, then, that a story so pregnant with dramatic possibilities should wind up feeling like such an unconsummated opportunity.
Calculated to outrage and executed to underwhelm, Kevin Smith's Red State is like a dull blade slashing wildly, predictably and ineffectually at its target.

Under Fire reckons with its subject in straightforward but engrossingly tough-minded fashion.
This alternately disturbing and titillating picture reps a dramatically misguided attempt to renew public awareness of the 1992-95 Balkan conflict.

Effortlessly blending wised-up, self-reflexive humor with old-fashioned let's-put-on-a-show pizzazz, The Muppets is an unexpected treat

A methodical, coolly absorbing boardroom thriller.

The film as a whole is best appreciated as a succession of richly rendered moods, plenty stimulating in the moment but rarely coalescing into something greater.

A draggy, generally laugh-free outing that wastes a perfectly good Anna Faris.
A noisy, f/x-spewing cauldron of a movie.

[An] intriguing but overly portentous drama, which seems far more taken with its own cynicism than most viewers will be.
An inventive marriage of ancient China and Agatha Christie.

The three leads are pitch-perfect here, loose and low-key yet fully in character.
What viewers are left with is a watchable enough picture that feels content to realize someone else's vision rather than claim it as its own.
A likable enough lark that rarely achieves outright hilarity.
Even Murphy's largely wordless, physically adroit performance can't redeem this tortured exercise in high-concept spiritualist hokum.

A viciously energetic South Africa-set actioner that makes up in sweaty atmosphere and brute force what it lacks in surprise.

A scattershot culture-clash comedy that goes down like yesterday's foie gras.

An affecting and immersive addiction drama about the unforeseen pitfalls along the road to recovery.

A small movie with a big heart, Safety Not Guaranteed is a sci-fi-tinged oddball comedy about love as the ultimate risky adventure.
Frivolous fun at best, archly affected tedium at worst.

This timely and involving documentary elicits both sympathy and schadenfreude.
This cloddishly contrived suspenser is too busy to bore, but too farfetched to thrill.
Reasonably swift and effective.
Steven Soderbergh's action-filmmaking chops get a swift, vigorous 92-minute workout in Haywire.

[A] harrowingly effective thriller.

Rudely funny and faintly melancholic... screenwriter John Michael McDonagh's directorial debut is a stylish lark whose many disparate elements somehow manage to go down as smoothly as Guinness.
That rare ensemble piece in which all four principals are not only compellingly drawn but handled with an astute sense of dramatic balance.
A quiet heartbreaker.
A lazy attempt to milk a few more laughs and bucks from the enormously lucrative property.
Neither smarter nor dumber than the average family-friendly comedy.
Johnny Depp, Angelina Jolie, Venice -- what more could you want from a movie? Quite a lot, actually.

movie_review_blurb: This feverishly creepy but dramatically miscalculated picture reps an unhappy marriage of murky psychodrama and dubious theorizing.

Lumbering and gripping by turns, and suffused with a profound sense of solitude and loss.

movie_review_blurb: What was briskly diverting in the original has been rather laboriously overworked, and the film's attempt to draw out the moral stakes never addresses the material's basic, surface-level implausibility.
Old-fashioned storytelling barely prevails over sassy contempo attitude.
Though enlivened by some moderately clever twists on the superhero-movie template, Megamind never shakes off a feeling of been-there-spoofed-that.
Snappy, saucy and, like any overzealous product-pusher, rather too eager to please.

The true dilemma of this misguided seriocomedy lies in the filmmakers' confusion as to whether they're making a side-splitting bromance (nope) or an unsparing, warts-and-all look at screwed-up relationships (sort of).

Few suffer as cheerfully for their art as Johnny Knoxville and his band of scatological stuntmeisters, and the gut-busting pleasure they take in every act of self-humiliation proves as infectious as ever.

This conventional but rousingly effective picture pulls through its occasional faltering stretches by focusing on the essentials of its incredible real-life saga, even if the details have been massaged for maximum uplift.
An amusing, light-footed caper about a team of aging CIA veterans rudely forced out of retirement.
Continues Fincher's fascinating transition from genre filmmaker extraordinaire to indelible chronicler of our times.
An inspiring true story is told with too many false notes and unexamined questions.
The filmmakers fully retain their offbeat sensibility and attentiveness to character while providing perhaps the sharpest showcase yet for Zach Galifianakis' outsized talents.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Affleck delivers another potent, serious-minded slice of pulp set on Boston's meanest streets, where loyalty among thieves runs thicker than blood.
An affectionate, raggedy road movie that feels like a throwback to more innocent times.
A bicoastal comedy with a bit of a bipolar disorder.
The food looks great, but the romance is undercooked, and God remains strictly a bit player.
A reliable guilty pleasure takes a dramatic step backward but a technological step forward.
A sprightly, generic kidpic that flattens and condenses elements from Beverly Cleary's deservedly popular novels.
Noyce rolls up his sleeves and delivers an unpretentious piece of action-movie craftsmanship that proves worthy of its star's own consummate professionalism.
Like a superior, state-of-the-art model built from reconstituted parts, Joss Whedon's buoyant, witty and robustly entertaining superhero smash-up is escapism of a sophisticated order.
An uneven but absorbing triptych of stories concerning the bonds between the living and the dead.

This genial if overlong romantic comedy bounces along on a steady stream of amusing moments, even as it presents the most polished and predictable version of a scenario that cries out for greater verbal and visual candor.

This high-end softcore thriller is juicily watchable from start to over-the-top finish, but its gleeful skewering of the upper classes comes off as curiously passe, a luxe exercise in one-note nastiness.
A subterranean survival epic that expertly tightens the screws even as one wishes it would keep a tighter mouth-clamp on its increasingly whiny characters.

movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: With its accelerated rhythm, relentless flow of incident and wizard-war endgame, Part 2 will strike many viewers as a much more exciting, involving picture than the slower, more atmospheric Part 1.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This foul-mouthed effort coasts on its leads' strong three-way chemistry and crack timing.
