movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Anais Demoustier and Romain Duris give beautifully controlled performances in Francois Ozon's delectably entertaining new film.
Taken strictly as a Cinemax-grade potboiler, "Missionary" is often a hoot, and more effective than it has any right to be.
The depths prove awfully shallow in this murky and derivative bayou gothic.
A fiendishly inventive thriller built around an audacious if unsustainable gimmick, Open Windows elevates Hitchcockian suspense to jittery new levels of mayhem and paranoia.
Where the picture excels is as a straightforward sports drama, and Caro delivers the satisfactions of the genre with unfussy verve.
A gripping, authoritative account of the myriad abuses of Warren Jeffs, the currently incarcerated leader of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
Rodney Ascher's follow-up to 'Room 237' is a unique hybrid of documentary and horror-thriller.

The combination of relentless forward drive and gruesomely fastidious detail, while audacious and admirable in theory, begins to pay dwindling returns in a picture that feels rather longer than its 122-minute running time.
A quietly captivating and remarkably beautiful account of Jesus' time in the wilderness before the beginning of his ministry.

Discerning arthouse-goers will warm to the film's superb performances, haunting sense of place and willingness to meander, as well as its sly rumination on the mysterious interplay of fate and friendship in shaping an individual's destiny.
'Starlet' helmer Sean Baker delivers another compassionate portrait of life on the L.A. margins with this big-hearted, low-budget tale of two transgender prostitutes.
A unique portrait of the Korean immigrant experience distinguishes writer-director Benson Lee's messy but endearing '80s-set comedy.
Writer-director Robert Eggers makes an impressive feature debut with this gripping historical horror-thriller.
This noisy, unappealing children's fantasy fails to distinguish itself among January's many, many reasons to steer clear of the multiplex.
A sporadically amusing, more often grating romantic comedy.

Bruce Willis plays the CEO of a futuristic resort where perfectly human-looking androids exist to fulfill their clients' deepest, darkest desires - none of which, it can safely be said, involve watching movies as relentlessly mediocre as this one.
For all [its] assets, "The Wedding Ringer" ultimately flattens out in all-too-familiar ways ...
A delicate study of a young woman extricating herself from the trappings of an outwardly successful life, "Something, Anything" marks a quietly assured feature debut for writer-director Paul Harrill.
[A] torturously unfunny exercise, which doesn't even rise to the level of competent misogyny ...
[A] creaky, listless affair ...
movie_title: Six Dance Lessons In Six Weeks (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A weirdly misshapen, fitfully intriguing depiction of one man's wayward quest for justice, plainly compromised in ways that only a director's cut could properly illuminate.
A bit embalmed in its own nobility, it's an extraordinary story told in dutiful, unexceptional terms, the passionate commitment of all involved rarely achieving gut-level impact.
The result feels less like a straightforward retread of the biblical narrative than an amped-up commentary on it: This "Exodus" comes at you in a heady and violent onrush of incident ...
An excremental but hardly execrable Australian comedy-drama that plays like the klutzy, sheets-soiling stepbrother of "Maria Full of Grace."
"Big Eyes" doesn't seem to trust either the factual truth or the emotional logic of the dilemma it's showing us.
Nuri Bilge Ceylan is at the peak of his powers with Winter Sleep, a richly engrossing and ravishingly beautiful magnum opus that surely qualifies as the least boring 196-minute movie ever made.
Inane and incredibly tasteless ...

This harrowing and intimate character study offers fairly blunt insights into the physical and psychological toll exacted on the front lines, yet strikes even its familiar notes with a sobering clarity ...

There's enough swaggering cynicism for three pictures but barely enough soul to sustain even one in Rupert Wyatt's "The Gambler," a stylish, energetic but disappointingly glib remake of Karel Reisz's still-potent 1974 drama of the same title.
The series' two-part finale gets under way in solid, absorbing if not exactly inspired fashion.

A bland and formulaic tale of two senior citizens who discover that it's never too late to fall in love - which may well be true, but doesn't keep this rickety recycling of a 2005 Spanish-Argentinean comedy from feeling long past its sell-by date.
Skillful as Marques-Marcet's aesthetic choices are, they wouldn't be half as effective without two such well-matched performances.

Actions, emotions and desperate impulses speak far louder than words in The Tribe, a formally audacious coup de cinema that marks a stunning writing-directing debut for Ukrainian filmmaker Myroslav Slaboshpytskiy.
The overall execution is so pedestrian that it's possible to feel more moved by the filmmakers' good intentions than by the actual emotional content onscreen.
Trite, flat-footed, culturally insensitive, and sagging under the weight of more than 25 credited producers ...
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Neither the script's up-to-the-minute signifiers nor its cheekily self-aware humor can entirely dispel a formulaic feel.

You need "The Expendables 3" like you need a kick in the crotch, and while this running-on-fumes sequel may not be quite as painful a thing to experience, it will waste considerably more of your time.
A slick, disposable soap opera about a poor white boy and a spirited Korean girl who fall in love despite hailing from rival corners of Brooklyn's club scene.
Leaves you feeling the film has somehow missed its mark, copping out with a mealymouthed, almost relativistic reading of the cosmic conundrum it has presented us with ...

A blandly executed action-thriller whose cast names (Matt Dillon, Willem Dafoe) and mild '80s Louisiana flavor offer only modest compensations for the story's workmanlike construction and routine twists.
A nifty found-footage thriller that marks a promising debut for writing-directing duo Clif Prowse and Derek Lee.

A serviceable Imax 3D nature documentary that duly meets the requirements of the form: majestic and intimate outdoor imagery, a grave yet reassuring lesson on the importance of wildlife preservation, and a short-and-sweet 40-minute running time.

Finally proves more exhausting than exhilarating as it lectures you about respecting Mother Nature one minute, knocks you over with a Gloria Gaynor cover the next, and squeezes in a lot of questionable comic relief in between.
Splendid views of marine life and the dulcet tones of narrator Cate Blanchett help a message of mild ecological alarm go down easily.
A complex, deeply sobering appraisal of the fallout from the BP oil spill.
The creative spark and sense of purpose are gone in this hokey transcontinental caper.
A creepy little diversion that ultimately unravels long before its hero's fragile psyche does.
A breakout performance by Sarah Snook distinguishes this entrancingly strange science-fiction drama.
Veronica is still hard as nails yet also, in her honest self-appraisal, as soft as a marshmallow - a description that unfortunately also applies to the movie.
Themes of isolation and friendship play out in another fine crop of Academy-nominated toon shorts.
Akiva Goldsman's feature-directing debut is a cloying, sledgehammer-subtle adaptation of Mark Helprin's vastly richer novel.
Wes Anderson's captivating 1930s-set caper offers a vibrant and imaginative evocation of a bygone era.
Paul Eenhoorn and Earl Lynn Nelson give pitch-perfect performances in this gently elegiac road comedy from helmers Martha Stephens and Aaron Katz.
[A] tough-minded, admirably unresolved film ...
A longer, slower, more expansive sequel that nevertheless delivers deep, bone-crunching pleasure for hardcore genre fans.
A brutal and merciless chase thriller that makes no apologies for its political one-sidedness and visceral extremity.
Philip Seymour Hoffman plays a German intelligence operative in Anton Corbijn's steadily absorbing John le Carre adaptation.
While it veers toward smugness and self-satisfaction at times, the Spike-Lee-lite exercise nonetheless heralds a fresh and funny new voice on the scene in writer-director Justin Simien ...
Brendan Gleeson gives a performance of monumental soul in John Michael McDonagh's masterful follow-up to 'The Guard.'
Keira Knightley gives a delightfully loose-limbed performance in Lynn Shelton's polished sixth feature.
A strained pileup of small-town stupidity that might more honestly have been titled "Sad Sacks 'R' Us."
Mark Ruffalo gives one of his most appealing performances in writer-director Maya Forbes' irresistible feature debut.
Hong Khaou makes a fine debut with this quietly resonant cross-cultural chamber piece.

The film is a brave act of witness complicated by the documaker's decision to re-create his experiences using clay figurines, a tricky aesthetic device that raises fascinating and problematic questions of representation.
This conspicuous attempt to breathe new life into a long-dormant action franchise gets at least a few things right, chiefly the shrewd casting of Chris Pine.
A lean and suspenseful genre piece that follows a bloody trail of vengeance to its cruel, absurd and logical conclusion.
This relentlessly mediocre ensemble dramedy features several of the least compelling dinner guests in recent memory.

There's something at once vividly familiar and strikingly different about "Knight of Cups," a feverish plunge into the toxic cloud of decadence swirling around a Los Angeles screenwriter gone to seed.
Beneath the wobbly pratfalls and the scatological setpieces, there's no denying the film's mean-spirited kick, or its more-than-passing interest in what makes its women tick.
A little-known tale of Jewish resistance during the final days of WWII gets tackled with appreciable ambition and blunt, sporadic emotional force in "Walking With the Enemy."
Hope Davis and David Duchovny give solid, moving performances as grieving parents in this inspirational heart-tugger.
Neither a particularly good movie nor the pop-cultural travesty that some were dreading.
It contrasts the heat and intensity of Indian cooking with the elegance and refinement of French haute cuisine, then balances the two with a feel-good lesson in ethnic harmony.
Scarlett Johansson and writer-director Luc Besson make an effective duo in this agreeably goofy sci-fi thriller.
An often tedious but clammily atmospheric end-of-the-world thriller set in the wake of a nuclear holocaust.
Idaho is the only thing that winds up looking good in this terminally trite dysfunctional-family melodrama.
Straw-man cinema doesn't get much more ludicrous than this heavy-handed, Christian-themed minister-on-the-run thriller.
"Sex Tape" is an unaccountable drag - strained, toothless and far too tame to achieve the sort of outrageous, raunchy-titillating effect it's aiming for.
Piles on the foreign accents and paint-by-numbers brutality, all served up with a grim, operatic self-seriousness that gives Cage's antihero little room to maneuver.
There are honestly stirring moments to be found in the movie's heartfelt tribute to the virtues of teamwork, courage and sacrifice, and in its soaring 3D visuals.
A well-meaning personal project that never rises above the level of amiable mediocrity ...

[The] surprises, while cleverly doled out over the film's brisk 88-minute running time, don't entirely offset the general displeasure of spending time with this particular circle of friends, lovers and old flames ...
Although funnier and mercifully shorter than its 2002 predecessor, this latest collaboration between director Tim Story and comedian Kevin Hart is a formulaic and exhausting experience.
Code Black feels like a brisk, vital report from the frontlines of emergency medicine, forged and rooted in the most intense sort of personal and professional experience.
Although stronger on breadth than focus, it's an appropriately stimulating take on a far-from-sustainable system ...

It's an affectionate, sometimes downright slobbery career salute with a soft, unexamined center - a moving experience for all involved, no doubt, but one of limited interest outside the celebrity bubble it depicts.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [Tully achieves] a winning innocence of spirit in which performances and production design are all perfectly synched to his low-key comic vision.
Multihyphenate Juno Mak makes his directing debut with this tedious tribute to Hong Kong's 'hopping vampires' subgenre.
Sebastian Junger delivers a worthy companion piece to 'Restrepo' with this more reflective dispatch from the front lines of Afghanistan.
Tom Cruise stars in this cleverly crafted and propulsively executed sci-fi thriller about a soldier forced to relive the same day over and over again.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Oscar winner Michel Hazanavicius makes a 180-degree shift from the effervescent charms of 'The Artist' with this grueling, lumbering and didactic war picture.
Ryan Gosling makes an altogether inauspicious debut with this risible slab of Detroit gothic.
Steve Carell, Mark Ruffalo and Channing Tatum give superb performances in Bennett Miller's powerfully disturbing true-crime saga.
This ludicrous abduction thriller plays like an ill-advised assembly of tropes and themes from Atom Egoyan's highlights reel.
Dana Ben-Ari's gently affecting and insightful documentary achieves a remarkable intimacy with its subjects.
Not since 2003's "X2: X-Men United" has this filmmaker tapped so effortlessly into his talent for comicbook gravitas, his ability to mine emotional resonance, pop poetry and (crucially) sly humor ...
"Oh, Toto, this doesn't look like the Oz I remember," Dorothy murmurs at one point. Truer words were never spoken.
A shrill feature-length sitcom for the faith-based family values crowd, if nowhere near as good as that sounds.
Incongruous as it may seem, the pleasures of Jane Austen and the horrors of the British slave trade make a surprisingly elegant and emotionally satisfying fit in Belle.
Delamarre knows his way around an action scene and keeps the proceedings moving briskly enough, even if the picture clocks in at about 10 minutes longer than its taut, 81-minute predecessor.
Glossy, well cast, and a consistent hoot until it becomes a serious drag.
Amir Bar-Lev offers a typically gripping and thoughtful take on the Penn State scandal.

Levine's script does a clever job of keeping numerous balls in the air over the taut 99-minute running time, and the writer is especially good at using the information he feeds us in unexpectedly resourceful, double-edged ways.
An inauspicious first entry in the Christian pro-wrestling vigilante movie subgenre.

Dormer is sympathetic enough in her double scream-queen roles, and Zada shows an occasional aptitude for generating suspense through framing, music and sound design, even if the beats he hits are often tediously familiar.
Beautiful and troubling.
For impressive stretches [Abrams] achieves the action-packed buoyancy of the old Saturday morning serials that partly inspired Star Wars in the first place.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The scenery ain't bad but the laughs are tumbleweed-sparse in "The Ridiculous 6," a Western sendup so lazy and aimless, it barely qualifies as parody.

[A] hauntingly beautiful new picture, which chronicles the gradual decline of a small coastal barrio in the Philippines in the final days before president Ferdinand Marcos imposed martial law in 1972.
movie_title: Mula sa kung ano ang noon (From What Is Before) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The mop is miraculous. David O. Russell's latest movie, not so much.
There is plenty of amazement here, to be sure, but all too little in the way of grace.
Krampus isn't especially scary, but it generates goodwill nonetheless for treating its home-invasion-for-the-holidays setup with an appreciably straight face.
A pedestrian retelling of a harrowing real-life survival story that served as one of the key inspirations for "Moby-Dick."
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This sprawling, blistering state-of-the-reunion-address is Spike Lee's most vital movie in years.
A profane thriller that so closely resembles the B-movies that followed "The Usual Suspects," "Pulp Fiction" and "Get Shorty," it could be mistaken for an archeological discovery.
The movie manages to register its own identity in gradual, piecemeal fashion, even as it doesn't deviate too dramatically from its predecessor's narrative template.
Ice Cube and Kevin Hart reteam, and add Ken Jeong to their ranks, in this tired, witless and potentially lucrative sequel.
An intimate and unnerving character study that marks a ferociously impressive feature debut for 26-year-old multihyphenate Trey Edward Shults.
A troubling study of denial, wartime responsibility and the challenge of dealing with a monster in the family.
movie_title: What Our Fathers Did: A Nazi Legacy (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An unabashed vanity project that struggles to turn its own beautiful inertia into a virtue.
Christian leaders calling for gun control are the subjects of Abigail Disney's intelligent and emotionally charged documentary.
The Scouts save the day, but not the movie, in this witless zombie-comedy retread.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Five stories by Edgar Allan Poe get varied treatment in this striking but inert animated compendium.
"India's Daughter" makes for grim, infuriating and sadly necessary viewing, its despair tinged with the faintest hope that the protestors' call for gender equality may yet be reignited.
A moody-foodie therapy session that follows an increasingly tidy narrative recipe as it sets this one-man kitchen nightmare on a long road to redemption.
The ravages of colonialism cast a dark pall over the stunning South American landscape in Embrace of the Serpent, the latest visual astonishment from the gifted Colombian writer-director Ciro Guerra.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Dev Patel and Jeremy Irons play real-life mathematicians in this plodding, overly dutiful biopic.
Johnnie To and Sylvia Chang's stage-to-screen musical is a dazzling entertainment set against the backdrop of the 2008 financial crisis.

Anthony Lucero's delectable debut feature has its share of on-the-nose writing and Cinderella-story contrivances, but for the most part folds its cross-cultural insights into a pleasing underdog narrative.
Jason Bateman proves that 'Bad Words' was no fluke with this sharp and affecting dysfunctional-family portrait.
Moorhouse's adaptation of Rosalie Ham's 2000 novel may lead audiences to expect a primmer, more well-behaved movie based on its title alone, but that doesn't mean it won't have them in stitches.
Cross-species bonding may have its limits, but it's hard not to find beauty in a boy-meets-beast saga that, by the end, has made it hard to tell which is which.
Bay has a genius for incoherence, and this is one historic crisis that feels uniquely suited to his dubious talents ...
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A winning lightness of touch prevails in this delightful continuation of the durable DreamWorks franchise.
Strong performances from Molly Shannon and Jesse Plemons help this often flailing cancer-themed seriocomedy find its footing.
Edgy and soft, audacious and coy, a largely enjoyable letdown.
Meghie's endearingly acerbic debut feature is a work of modest ambition and commercial outlook, but that modesty proves intrinsic to its appeal ...
A documentary that works as both an emotional portrait of a slow-motion family tragedy and a slippery inquiry into the therapeutic properties of making art.
There's a lot going on in Midnight Special, but Nichols is a classicist who takes his rhythms from his rural American settings, and he doles out details at a pace that feels urgent yet measured.
Touches a chord of bittersweet feeling that a more genre-oriented thriller approach might not have managed.
A well-acted and involving dramedy that takes a few too many facile turns en route to upbeat endings all around.
Josh Locy makes a beguiling directing debut with this curious tale of an ex-con trying to get his life back on track.
Cage supplies a stream of tension-defusing laughs while the script steadily applies the screws, but this disposable exercise in comic nihilism offers only a modest payoff at best.

An initially amusing but fatally overstretched action-comedy that marks a lamer-than-expected big-screen outing for Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele following the conclusion last year of their frequently brilliant cable series.
Few filmmakers have so fully embraced the bittersweet joy of living in the moment - one that's all the more glorious because it fades so soon.
A sensationally effective semi-sequel that bears virtually no narrative or stylistic resemblance to its predecessor ...
The movie never quite shakes off a glib, incurious outsider's perspective that can tilt into outright cluelessness, particularly where some of its more egregious casting choices are concerned.

This martial-arts mediocrity has airborne warriors aplenty but remains a dispiritingly leaden affair with its mechanical storytelling, purely functional action sequences and clunky English-language performances.
movie_title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This is by any measure a dreadful movie, a chintzy, CG-encrusted eyesore that oozes stupidity and self-indulgence from its every pore.
Shadow delivers the sort of sleek, swiftly paced freakout that streaming customers will gladly look past subtitles to experience.
A teasingly effective thriller that builds a remarkable level of tension over the course of its 99-minute running time.

Whether or not it triggers a craze for divinely inspired detective stories, "Risen" makes a decent case for itself as the "Columbo" of the genre: It's amiable, creaky and not remotely predicated on the element of surprise.
A modern-day heist thriller of unusually grim, coiled intensity ...
The orange mocha crappuccino of movie sequels.
Ryan Reynolds gets the full-throttle wisecracking showcase he deserves in this scabrously funny origin story.
Roger Ross Williams' captivating documentary explores a young autistic man's growth and progress through his obsession with Disney animated movies.
Debuting writer-director Nate Parker stars in this searingly impressive account of the Nat Turner slave rebellion.
"Lovesong" makes a virtue of restraint as it traces a complex emotional history in two parts, and innumerable (and sometimes quite literal) shades of gray.
To shackle two lovely and promising teenage actresses to material this dreadful could be reasonably construed as an awfully expensive form of child abuse.
Tika Sumpter and Parker Sawyer are terrifically cast as younger versions of Michelle and Barack Obama in Richard Tanne's disarmingly romantic walkabout.
A supremely elegant and delicately filigreed adaptation of Jane Austen's epistolary novella "Lady Susan."

These discrete "reveries of the connected world" represent the latest of Herzog's heady explorations of what it means to be human (and even post-human), rendered in his characteristically personal, decidedly analog style.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Craig Robinson and Markees Christmas play a father and son forging a new life in Germany in Chad Hartigan's winsome coming-of-ager.

"Sky Ladder" may not fully penetrate the mystery of Cai's artistic identity, but it ends with the poignant suggestion that the most significant accomplishments often stem from the simplest, most personal impulse.
movie_title: Sky Ladder: The Art of Cai Guo-Qiang (2016)

movie_review_blurb: At times plays like a period piece, populated by cardboard bigots, flamboyant gay crusaders and other hoary relics of a less enlightened past. That may be cause for celebration, but it's hardly a compliment.
Cate Blanchett and Robert Redford star in James Vanderbilt's crisp and fastidious account of the Killian documents affair.
An inside-showbiz lark that regards the 1950s studio system with the utmost skepticism even as it becomes an expression of movie love at its purest.
An expectedly stirring portrait of the exceedingly smart and courageous Pakistani teenager who defied the Taliban and lived to tell the tale.
A drama of redemption by way of an American Revolution history lesson, Chad Burns' action-adventure yarn offers little in the way of subtlety or surprise.
Shu Qi plays the eponymous killer in this ravishingly beautiful foray into historical martial-arts territory from Taiwanese master Hou Hsiao-hsien.
For all its initial narrative intrigue and visual splendor, winds up feeling like a hollow, hucksterish Trojan horse of a movie ...

An exquisitely drawn, deeply felt love story that teases out every shadow and nuance of its characters' inner lives with supreme intelligence, breathtaking poise and filmmaking craft of the most sophisticated yet accessible order.
It's a movie that hits every one of its ideological targets, but still winds up missing the mark.
Hungarian helmer Laszlo Nemes and actor Geza Rohrig make a powerful debut with this grim, unyielding Holocaust drama.

John Maclean's impeccably crafted writing-directing debut at times has a distinctly Coen-esque flavor in its mix of sly intelligence, bleak humor and unsettling violence, exuding fierce confidence even when these qualities don't always cohere.

Thirty years have passed since our last visit to George Miller's sun-scorched post-apocalyptic wasteland, and yet "worth the wait" still seems a puny response to the two hours of ferocious, unfettered B-movie bliss offered by "Mad Max: Fury Road."

Hunt hurls herself headlong into the role of this stubborn, controlling, self-satisfied, intensely judgmental woman, making it all the more gratifying when her veneer of self-possession begins to crack and we begin to warm to her in spite of ourselves.
Blake Lively's subtle, expressive performance sets the tone for this thoroughly ludicrous, thoroughly enjoyable romantic drama.
The problem here isn't theological; even if it were in service of a different message entirely, the sheer gracelessness of Monteverde's storytelling would be a massive turnoff.
Kevin James keeps falling on his face and colliding with heavy objects, this time in Vegas, in this tacky, numbingly inane sequel.
It does offer an appreciably even-handed, non-judgmental panorama of teens and adults flailing their way toward a place of greater empathy and understanding ...
There remains a nagging tidiness to the whole endeavor that leaves a strained, cloying aftertaste.
Two separated siblings are reunited in Samantha Futerman and Ryan Miyamoto's irresistible documentary.
Seems less and less convincing the more blatantly it strives for authenticity.

If you're disturbed by white-collar crime, but not quite as disturbed as you are by gay sex, then congratulations: You might possess just the right combo of social conscience and unexamined homophobia needed to fully enjoy Get Hard.
Owen has floundered of late in his search for a big-screen vehicle worthy of his talents, and "Last Knights" doesn't exactly buck the trend.
A delicate, elliptically structured portrait of six wounded souls coping with the aftermath of tragedy.
Alex Gibney takes on Steve Jobs and society's ongoing Apple addiction in this deeply critical biographical portrait.
movie_title: Steve Jobs: Man in the Machine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: What really fascinates is the comedy of errors -- and manners -- that Hausner stages along the way, commenting sardonically on the various mishaps, misunderstandings and missed connections that ensue.
Liam Neeson does his thing, and does it well, in this robustly satisfying Irish-American mob thriller.
This dismal stab at a darkly comic thriller is hardly the vehicle to resuscitate its lead actress's bigscreen career, but it's unlikely to do much for anyone else's, either.
Zephyr Benson wrote, directed, produced and starred in this fitfully engaging but unconvincing account of his own tumultous, drug-addled youth.
A robot-themed action movie that winds up feeling as clunky and confused as the childlike droid with which it shares its name.
Awkwardly wrapping a heartwarming message of self-acceptance in a layer of crude sexual humor, it's like a date who tries to pat you on the back with one hand while feeling you up with the other.
Salma Hayek plays a sex slave turned killer in this stylish but lumbering actioner.
Michael Moore goes on a global tour with this impishly entertaining polemic.
Internal logic ... lends "Hot Tub Time Machine 2" not only its rough-and-ready comic vigor, but also a surprising measure of thematic integrity.
This poignant slice-of-life dramedy proves as modest in length (78 minutes) as it is generous in rueful insight and emotional complexity ...
The undeniable intensity of Gyllenhaal's bulked-up, Method-mumbling performance may leave you feeling more pummeled than convinced in this heavy-handed tale of redemption ...
Melissa McCarthy gets the funniest, most versatile and sustained comic showcase of her movie career in this deliriously entertaining action-comedy.
A clumsily told story of friendship and wartime remembrance that has a tough time serving up a halfway believable moment, let alone a moving and powerful testimony about the Lordship of Jesus Christ.
The movie's willingness to veer crazily off-course feels less objectionable than the monotony and sense of self-parody that kick in long before the whimper of a finish.
Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay give this truncated but still-powerful adaptation of Emma Donoghue's novel its beating heart.

A superbly controlled and engrossingly detailed account of the Boston Globe's Pulitzer Prize-winning investigation into the widespread pedophilia scandals and subsequent cover-ups within the Catholic Church.

The unsentimental education of an African child soldier is captured with savage beauty and matter-of-fact horror in "Beasts of No Nation," a tough-minded, tough-viewing chronicle of a civil war as seen through the eyes of one of its youngest casualties.
Although hardly a peak achievement, Baltasar Kormakur's Himalayan epic is a properly grueling, strikingly unsentimental chronicle of the 1996 Mount Everest tragedy.
It's a measure of the film's dramatic balance as well as its emotional integrity that both of these men will wind up eliciting the viewer's sympathy and scorn at different points.

"We Are Your Friends" increasingly plays like a synth-heavy soap opera ("As the Table Turns," anyone?) that doesn't so much delve into the EDM phenomenon so much as scan it for easy dramatic hooks and emotional entry points.
A technically accomplished, morally rank slab of cultural exploitation ...
The Hollywood romantic comedy hits an astonishing new low with this disastrous pairing for Pierce Brosnan and Salma Hayek.
An enthralling performance by Michael Fassbender fuels this brilliant, infuriating and richly unconventional take on the life of an American visionary.

This debut feature for director Amin Dora and scribe Georges Khabbaz may be as simple-minded as the characters it scrutinizes and finds wanting. But it demonstrates a deft, winning touch all the same.

What to call it, exactly? The 47th best action film of 2015? A feature-length Audi commercial, or a promo reel for the Singapore Tourism Board? The most unnecessary artistic contribution ever made by someone named Bach?
[6 Years] too often veers toward melodramatic overstatement, inspiring little empathy or understanding despite the committed performances of promising young leads Taissa Farmiga and Ben Rosenfield.
This patchy, underwritten thriller could almost pass for a critique of any number of genre forebears in which the mere presence of a hot, ass-kicking female avenger is meant to seem subversive.
A slender, morally simplified fable that makes up for its tonal and narrative imprecisions with considerable visual energy, musical pizzazz, and a panoply of colorful characters ...

Essentially an 84-minute shoulder shrug captured onscreen, "Big Significant Things" is the latest American independent feature to suggest there are few things more intriguing than a young white guy trying to find himself.
It may not subvert every cliche of the high-school romance genre, but director Jake Schreier's coming-of-age dramedy nonetheless pulses with moving and melancholy moments ...
Ultimately a sweet, simple ode to the virtues of honesty and commitment in a relationship, "Arlo & Julie" may be a trifle at day's end, but it's a deft and pleasurable one.
Succeeds well enough as a genial diversion and sometimes a delightful one, predicated on the rarely heeded Hollywood wisdom that less really can be more.
The narrative machinery proves no more convincing than the underlying subtext.
A contrived but weirdly compelling thriller involving a tortured hitman, his willing prey, and the inexplicable curse that keeps them both from realizing their shared goal.
There's precious little charm or magic in this English-dubbed, German-produced fairy-tale mash-up.
A bland and unremarkable tale of sad souls and dead-end circumstances from first-time feature director Tony Aloupis.
Plays like a series of hand-holding growth exercises for closed-minded conservatives, and relies too heavily on its tying-the-knot finale for both dramatic momentum and emotional closure.
A picture whose politics prove rather more commendable than its artistry.
The latest gently hypnotic cinematic enigma from the Thai writer-director Apichatpong Weerasethakul.
A dimwitted '80s nostalgia trip best appreciated by those who have waited years for Adam Sandler's fine-grained intelligence and Chris Columbus' filmmaking mastery to finally converge.
Mark Neveldine's first solo directorial effort is a silly, shrieky and eminently watchable exorcism thriller.
At once questioning and reaffirming the pleasures of cinematic espionage, this is the rare sequel that leaves its franchise feeling not exhausted but surprisingly resurgent at 19 years and counting.
Arnaud Desplechin and Mathieu Amalric revisit the adventures of Paul Dedalus in this marvelously vivid coming-of-age drama.
movie_title: My Golden Days (Trois Souvenirs De Ma Jeunesse) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You get the sense that Stone recruited these guys to help him pitch a package to general audiences.

Ideally, the stakes of Kondabolu's documentary are higher than just the future of The Simpsons or Hank Azaria's esteem...unfortunately, Kondabolu stops short of imagining a better version of The Simpsons or a world beyond Apu.
Essentially, Death Note is a serialized detective drama in which two strange wise guys face off to prove their superior wits. It's not that deep.
As a record-label history lesson, Can't Stop, Won't Stop is incomplete. As a concert doc, it's a rough ride for the viewer.
movie_title: Can't Stop, Won't Stop: A Bad Boy Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Linda Hamilton gets so little due respect over the years for how much of the film's midsection rides on her.
Jeremy Snead's doc comes off more as a commercial for a grand, overarching product that isn't finished being developed.
The strange, ambitious character work that comprises Batman Returns is wrapped in the perfunctory framework of a Tim Burton superhero film.
"Warm Bodies" doesn't break any new ground or change the face of zombie cinema. It's just a fun, hokey love story... with a bite. A perfect date film, you know, for those who love to love zombies.
Schwarzenegger is back, and his timing couldn't be any worse. At a time when violence in movies is being scrutinized, Arnold arrives with a no-holds-barred shoot-em-up in "The Last Stand."

Somewhere in this hyper-stylized actioner are remnants of some previously-conceived film, a better movie that feels as if it has been methodically stripped down over time, losing the pulpiness of the genre to the video game culture.
The Cabin in the Woods is a quick-witted, mind-bending fright fest. A truly rare and original horror film.
While the film may not be the best of the year, its true winner is Jessica Chastain's knock-out, Oscar-worthy performance.

Tarantino blends the Spaghetti western genre with 70s Blaxploitation, creating an insane concoction of vengeance and thoughtfulness, tossing between the disgustingly funny and the most primal notion of violence.

It would be wrong to ignore the technical achievement that Jackson has pulled off yet again. But when said and done, "The Hobbit" feels more like a cinematic encyclopedia of Tolkein's mythical world rather than a trip to the movies.
While "Identity Thief" isn't one of the best road-trip movies to come our way, Melissa McCarthy makes the journey worth it.
If you are able to look past the giant commercial elephant in the room, "The Internship" is actually a sweet throwback to the formulaic comedies of the late 1970s and 1980s
Zack Snyder, Christopher Nolan and David S. Goyer have managed to become Superman's very own Kryptonite, stripping the iconic character of his greatest assets: wit, charm, and most importantly, hope.
"Life of Pi" is a graceful picture and does what movies do best: it tells a great story and shows a piece of our world with clear, wide-open eyes.
Though "Lincoln" feels more like a play than a film, and will appeal mostly to history and political buffs, it is one of Steven Spielberg's best and most important movies.
"Skyfall" is the best of the Daniel Craig Bond films and surpasses just about every Bond film made in the past 43 years. Not only is this a great Bond movie, it's a great film.
Robert Zemeckis' return to live-action filmmaking after nearly a decade of animated films, is mostly a slick and smooth ride, marred by only a few unnecessary jolts of turbulence.

"Cloud Atlas" should not work. But it does. Lana Wachowski, Andy Wachowski and Tom Tykwer have wrangled David Mitchell's beast of a story and delivered a haunting, full-bodied tour de force, and a completely unprecedented movie experience
A gutsy blend of suspense and off-the-wall humor, "Argo" will immediately grab you from the rush of its prologue and not let go until the end credits roll.
Watching Hopkins and Mirren transform into these characters is a must-see. While the movie is far from perfect, these two actors are perfect.
There's little to take away from "Hyde Park" apart from Bill Murray's electrifying performance as Roosevelt
If we are to believe "Side Effects" is Steven Soderbergh's final theatrical film before his retirement from movies, then he couldn't have gone out on a more electrifying film.
An American gothic soap opera and dark coming-of-age film that benefits greatly from its chilling atmosphere and stellar performances by Mia Wasikowska, Nicole Kidman and Matthew Goode.
With "After Earth," Smith can't even save himself, his film, or his director
The weakest of the three films and should really only appeal to diehard fans of the franchise. The film is billed as "the end," and it's a relief that this hangover has finally subsided.
"Into Darkness" is a warp-speed ride of intense suspense, lens flares, mystery and thrills, dipping in and out of "Star Trek" lore and ultimately creating a fresh new direction.
Certainly people will have their opinions when it comes to Luhrmann's bohemian style, but Fitzgerald's book lends itself very well to this adaptation.
Perhaps returning to his roots did the visionary director a great service since this "Frankenweenie" is the best Burton film in well over a decade.
Not only is "Iron Man 3" the best of the trilogy, it's the best Marvel film yet. Yes, even better than last summer's uber-blockbuster "The Avengers."
For his first post-"Transformers" production, Bay goes a little too far at making stupidity and violence appear alluring and sexy.
Forget what you know about the earlier "Die Hard" films. This 'Good Day' is not the "Die Hard," nor the John McClane that we've come to know.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: From the get-go it's easy to assume this film will become a sci-fi classic. But as "Oblivion" crosses the threshold from the unknown to the all-too-obvious, the Tom Cruise alien adventure falls into familiar territory.
With a dash of gritty crime drama, truly compelling characters and top-notch acting from Cooper and Gosling, Derek Cianfrance's "The Place Beyond the Pines" is a must-see.
The sequel erases the absurd campiness of Stephen Sommers' original and attempts a reboot at becoming the next bad-ass action franchise, but in the end is nothing more than your average "Joe."
Tina Fey and Paul Rudd are a dream team in this light-hearted drama.
'The Incredible Burt Wonderstone' isn't breaking comedic ground, nor is it 'incredible,' but there is something magical about seeing Carell, Carrey, Buscemi and Arkin together.
Though "Emperor" is a mystery of which we already know the ending, director Peter Webber ("Girl with a Pearl Earring") keeps the story moving and interesting.
"Oz" suffers from a gluttonous use of CGI and an incredibly weak story, but the biggest problem is James Franco as the titular character.
Bryan Singer's "Jack the Giant Slayer" is a gentle giant, a short and sweet climb that's fun all the way up the bean stalk.
A fine drama which throws no curves, allowing for an easy hit. You'll be hard-pressed to not feel inspired by film's end.

"Looper" is a welcome return to smart science fiction. It's more than just a popcorn film. It's a drama that uses an age-old genre device to play a fantastic moral game of cat and mouse. A definite must-see.
It was only a matter of time before Ferrell and Galifianakis crossed swords on screen, and the combination of their distinctive styles of humor are as natural as a politician kissing a baby.
A dark, gory and incredibly violent crime fighting film that is the antithesis to the flood of fluffy comic book movies of late.

If Cecil B. DeMille were alive today and given the chance to direct a special effects-laden fantasy adventure on Mars, he might have made something similar to Andrew Stanton's visually stunning epic "John Carter."
Paul Dano is a shining beacon in the bleak and disconnected indie drama.
"The Words" tries to meticulously paint a picture with a broad brush, thus smearing the details and creating a different piece than perhaps intended.
"Ted" is what happens when you give the creator of "Family Guy" the freedom of an R-rating and a big budget - and the final product is nothing short of raunchy, comedy gold.
It's good to have another Soderbergh movie, and one that's completely different from anything he's done before. But beneath the magic, "Mike" is ultimately meh.
"Beasts of the Southern Wild" is an odd, poetic and singular vision.
"The Amazing Spider-Man" would be amazing if we didn't just see it a few years ago.
A fun caper thinly veiled as a supernatural thriller - a mystery loaded with all the tricks and devices recently made popular by M. Night Shyamalan.
Recall the original.
You can do yourself a solid and save some money on future therapy sessions by letting Meryl Streep, Tommy Lee Jones and Steve Carell guide you.
Though the weakest of the series, "The Bourne Legacy" is not a throw-away action film. It's one of the best thrillers of the year and a sure bet on the future success of the "Bourne" franchise.
"The Odd Life of Timothy Green" is not your garden-variety feel-good kids' film, but it's a quirky, tender and mature ode to parenting that is equally entertaining for adults and children.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Cosmopolis" is proof that a film can be provocative yet completely un-enjoyable.
Unequivocally original with breathtaking stop-motion animation (stay to the end of the credits for a very brief demo of Norman's creation), "ParaNorman" is easily the best animated film of the year.

With outstanding production design and one of the best ensembles of the year, John Hillcoat and Nick Cave have given us a deliciously full keg of story and character from which to replenish ourselves.
The Sam Raimi-produced "The Possession" enters the ring against the classic heavyweight champion "The Exorcist" and is embarrassingly smote during the first round.
Certainly one of the most eccentric and imaginative films of the summer.
With the most preposterous of plots, one would expect "Lincoln" to be funny, but it's not. It takes itself as seriously as a disease, and therein lies the biggest problem with this film.
Clint Eastwood plus America's pastime should have been a grand slam, but the tender yet predictable drama "Trouble with the Curve" is more of a stand up double.

Each scene plays out like a cleverly crafted vignette that gives the film a freshness and propulsion often missing from the romantic comedy genre. It also doesn't hurt to throw the looming apocalypse in there for good measure.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There are two reasons to see "Rock of Ages." One: If you live and breathe for 80s rock music. Two: A drugged up Tom Cruise belting out Bon Jovi. Unfortunately, that's about it.
An elegantly crafted potboiler that fires on all cylinders, giving Gere his juiciest role yet.
Chilling, hypnotic and strikingly beautiful. Joaquin Phoenix and Philip Seymour Hoffmann are electrifying, like two expert magicians at the top of their game.
Denzel and Reynolds keep the bulk of the film fresh, gritty and intense.
While everyone has their tastes and limits there must be a line when a film is so shameless in its lack of dignity and intellect and assumes the audience are just a bunch of rubes.
"Wrath of the Titans" is like a shiny Mylar balloon that pops to reveal nothing inside but empty, stale air.
Featuring beautiful cinematography that captures the natural beauty of the Rockies and a superlative cast, Lawrence and Meg Kasdan's "Darling Companion" is a darling of a film.
Jason Statham's latest actionpalooza "Safe" is unsuitably hilarious, although that's probably not the film's intended reaction.
Despite Cuasck's occasional missteps as the writer, "The Raven" is an entertaining thriller.
The Jason Segel-Emily Blunt romcom has a cold, standoffish first act but ultimately warms up, becoming a genuinely sweet romantic comedy.
Marvel's "The Avengers" is the super-hero movie to end all super-hero movies. Why? Joss Whedon.
While "Dark Shadows" has many wonderful elements, it is set up to become a new franchise for Warner Bros, but it just doesn't quite have that eternal bite.
It appears a Hollywood boardroom has scraped the bottom of the barrel of originality to come up with a very long, very loud movie with almost nothing new to say.
Like so many sequels, "MIB3" lacks the charisma of the original "Men In Black."

Wes Anderson's refreshingly original "Moonrise Kingdom" is an unconventional children's adventure for adults, filled with with striking colors, textures and humor, and teeming with childhood innocence.
While it's a heavily flawed film, there's more good than bad to be found in this adaptation of the Grimm tale.
"For Greater Glory" takes its cues from a bygone era of Technicolor Golden Age epics and delivers a sprawling political drama steeped in old-fashioned Hollywood romanticism.
Returning to the genre that skyrocketed his career with "Alien" and "Blade Runner," Scott has fashioned a fascinating new mystery within his original "Alien" universe.
Overflowing with heart, vibrant color, thrilling adventure, and with a bold new protagonist to add to the Disney canon, Pixar's "Brave" is a wonderfully unique spin on the classic princess tale.
The silly characters are the heart and center of the film and kids will most likely be racing out for their very own "Turbo" action figures
With the current crop of heavy films in theaters, "Last Vegas" is a crowd-pleasing, light-hearted alternative.
Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg's buddy action-comedy "2 Guns" is an unexpected dog-days-of-summer surprise.
"Dawn of the Planet of the Apes" is not only the best sequel in the franchise and one of the best films of 2014, it's the best science fiction film in years.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Melissa McCarthy is back with "Tammy," one of her strongest roles yet -- a result of her direct creative control on this project -- but apart from her performance, this road-trip comedy unfortunately coasts by on autopilot.

Since this genre has more than exhausted itself over three and a half decades, writers Michael Bacall, Oren Uziel and Rodney Rothman are smart to hold a mirror up to the buddy cop genre, generating the comedy through self-awareness and self-deprecation.
A surprising and unforgettable adrenaline rush and is so far the summer's best action film.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: With Singer back at the helm and a marvelous cast to boot, "X-Men: Days of Future Past" is the best in the franchise and possibly the best superhero film yet this year.
Gareth Edward's "Godzilla" remake is the best creature-feature since Steven Spielberg's "Jurassic Park", once again returning awe and wonder to the summer blockbuster season.

"Neighbors" - or more aptly 'get off my lawn: the movie' - is suburbia's worst nightmare: a quiet young family versus the horde of an unruly, perverse and destructive frat house. Equal parts heart and raunch, this latest Seth Rogen gem is all laughs.
For fans of the book and of David Fincher's previous films, "Gone Girl" is a must-see. It's also cheaper than couple's counseling.

Andrew Garfield and Emma Stone return as Peter Parker and Gwen Stacey in this long - very long - two and a half hour long - did we mention its long? - sequel. They didn't quite use their spidey-sense in the cutting room.

"Winter Soldier" is a nod to the great espionage films of the 1970s, movies like "3 Days of the Condor" and "The Parallax View," even going so far to bridge the two by casting "Condor" star Robert Redford as shady politician Alexander Pierce.
The Muppets are on the lam in "Muppets Most Wanted," but sorry, these aren't the Muppets you're looking for.
"Non-Stop" is nothing but entertaining; a locked-room mystery combining elements of Agatha Christie and "Air Force One."

Clooney has certainly created a throwback to old Hollywood war films, which is fine, but almost unsure of his own recipe, throws far too many ingredients into the mix ultimately creating a war film that is indeed enjoyable but suffers an identity crisis.
"Labor Day" suffers from the age-old plot-line that a crestfallen woman is seemingly emotionally paralyzed and incapable of helping herself until Prince Charming comes to the rescue.
Tracy Letts' adaptation of his Pulitzer Prize-winning play is catnip for actors and raises dysfunction to a whole new level.
Wild, offbeat and insane, "The Wolf of Wall Street" is one of the year's best films and a definite career-topper for DiCaprio who, with Scorsese, have given us another phenomenal collaboration
Whedon is beloved for his work in genre film and television ("Buffy the Vampire Slayer"), but he excels here with a more intimate story.
For a film completely drenched with sentimentality about faith, hope and human-kind's resolve, "Interstellar" is at times as cold and lifeless as a vacuum.

'Mockingjay, Part 1" is only half awesome because it is only half a movie. Suzanne Collins' final book in the trilogy has been segmented into two films, massacring the momentum the previous films had delicately built.
A must-see movie, a gorgeous and inspiring film that showcases Reese Witherspoon at her Oscar-worthy best
"Black Panther" features all the right ingredients to become one of the most successful superhero films of all time.
"Rogue One" is pure, unbridled "Star Wars."
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With an impeccable mix of live action, CGI and a stampede of adventure, "The Jungle Book" proves Disney is once again king of the jungle.
"Star Wars: The Force Awakens" is the "Star Wars" sequel we have been looking for: a classic adventure that harkens back to the glory days of 1977's "Star Wars" and 1980's "The Empire Strikes Back."
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While "Red 2" is a fairly traditional espionage film with a comedic twist and brilliant cast, the film is ultimately as Hopkins' character frequently quips: "Jolly good."
"Spectre" feels too much like a franchise in frustrating flux, which has more of a negative than positive effect.
Atypical casting and xenophobia are alive and well in the white-knuckle thriller "No Escape."
Henry Cavill, Armie Hammer, Alicia Vikander, Elizabeth Debicki and a delightfully cavalier visual aesthetic return the fun and levity to the spy genre.
If only one thing should be taken away from this film, it's that the Streep acting genes will surely live on for a long time to come through the superb Mamie Gummer
With spectacular effects and an engaging story, X-Men: First Class is a standout period adventure film that just happens to be about superheroes.
The year is only half over but the sheer originality and soul in "Inside Out" easily puts it as one of 2015's best films. A definite must-see for the whole family.
Whether or not there was any real demand for another "Jurassic Park" movie, "Jurassic World" proves that it's still tons of fun to run with dinosaurs.
A steampunk fever dream, a hallucinatory and vicious drive through hell, and 70-year-old director George Miller is behind the wheel ... having a lovely, lovely day.
"Avengers: Age of Ultron" brings the best of all the Marvel worlds for the first explosive superhero thrill-ride of the year.

The fine line between abuse and pleasure is so thin it's almost non-existent. Here is a Valentine's Day movie that will certainly make bank, but you aren't helping yourself or anyone else by seeing it.
The tale of the burglar Hobbit Bilbo Baggins limps - no, crawls - to a disappointing and profoundly underwhelming finish.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Overall "Still Alice" feels rather incomplete, but the blemishes are overshadowed by some tender and potent moments, a lovely score by Ilan Eshkeri and Julianne Moore's fantastic performance.

An awkward start, especially as it takes a moment to get used to Russell's style and tone, but once "Hustle" finds its footing it really takes off and is one of the most intelligent and enjoyable films of the year.

"The Hobbit" has been saved... at least for the time being. "The Desolation of Smaug" is a vast improvement over the first installment and is an excellent return to the level of quality as "The Lord of the Rings."
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Jennifer Lawrence carries the entire weight of the movie and helps solidify this as a satisfying movie franchise
A potboiler with three incredible performances by Bale, Affleck and Harrelson, "Out of the Furnace" is a film with many superb parts that falls slightly short of making a cohesive whole.
It's a pity Streep can't be picked up as Thatcher like a chess piece and placed down in a different, better film.
Eric Roth's nimble screenplay and composer Alexandre Desplat's delicate score also help solidify "Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close" as one of the best movies movies of 2011
After an interesting guessing game in the first forty minutes, it slips and falls to a terrible and clichéd death.
Soderbergh rocks this genre and Carano gives any male action star a run for his money.

"The Grey" is a film that reminds us how fortunate we are to be sitting in a theater or at home on the couch and not suffering frostbite, hypoxia and being in the dastardly predicament of having giant wolf fangs ripping our innards inside out.
"Big Miracle" is quite the whale of a tale. Miraculous? Maybe. Predictable? Mostly. Delightful? Absolutely.
Scene after endless scene of Radcliffe roaming the hallways of a spooky gothic house seeking the source of creepy noises and phantasmic movements is not compelling enough for a two-hour film.
Boasting an exotic trip around the world, an engaging script, funny dialogue and spectacular stunts, "Ghost Protocol" is an adrenaline-rush adventure on a grand scale.
A blisteringly intense master-class in suspense and character.
Struggling with warts and all, "Passion" is a loopy but fun late-night thriller brimming with style and vitality from one of America's most exciting film makers.
A delightful and natural exploration of friendship that is at once honest, refreshingly funny and uncomfortably real.
The world doesn't end with a whimper, but with ingenious laughter, making this off-the-chart genre-bending comedy the funniest and most original movie of the summer.

"Paranoia" should be commended for attempting to give younger audiences something more mature to digest at the movies, but unfortunately once the film hits a dead zone, the reception is lost for good.
This superbly crafted and impeccably acted civil rights drama is the first major Oscar contender of the year.

People expecting another "District 9" or who expect a little more substance from their science fiction films will most likely be disappointed by "Elysium," but those who like their videogame-style sci-fi shoot-em-ups will have no problem here.

Emma Thompson's brilliant performance, a story that captures the joy and heartache of creation, the nostalgia of the Sherman brothers' classic songs, combined with Thomas Newman's bittersweet original score, make this a sweetheart of a picture.
"The Family" may not be top tier De Niro, but it is excellent Pfeiffer and a welcome return for director Luc Besson.
Steven Spielberg's "War Horse" is an imperfect film, but certainly is a beautiful one.
A solid effort in the road trip genre and features more laughs than not.
The second installment in the series, churns like a lump of moldy dough sitting in the pit of your stomach, trying ever so hard to be digested.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: "Catching Fire" confidently charges full-on into the flames and the result is spectacular.

The biggest assets to any classic Disney musical are the songs, and the tunes in "Frozen" just happen to be the weakest link, making this attempt to return to the glory days of "The Little Mermaid" and "Aladdin," an arduous, frigid journey.

A beautiful, timeless American film whose story, characters and performances should be treasured. This is one of the year's best films and once again, Alexander Payne has given us a tender, poetic masterpiece.
A beautiful exploration of compassion during war with some truly marvelous performances. A must-see.
Visually triumphant and chock-full of classic Spielberg-isms -- both good and bad.
Despite the unfortunate controversy surrounding the book's author, the cast and crew of "Ender's Game" collectively make this a late-year surprise and a damn good science fiction film.
An odd yet fascinating extension to [Cormac McCarthy's] violent literary oeuvre.
Fans of '80s and '90s action films should revel in its awesome nostalgia.
Marvel Studios has unleashed their most outlandish (literally) and off-the-wall craziest entry in their entire canon.
"12 Years" is a tour de force, just one of the most unpleasant ones you will ever see.
"Captain Phillips" features Tom Hanks at the top of his game. It's hands-down one of the year's best films.
As of right now, there's just nothing else like it. And that is a rare treat at the movies.
With an undeniably effective immediacy, "Rush" is a solid, but rather cold, biopic about two equally detached personalities.
"Hugo" is a magical cinematic experience, and a masterpiece so unlike anything Scorsese has made before. Captivating and original, it is the director's most human film yet.
"Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy," with its meticulous Cold War details and labyrinthine plot, is like a smoky 25-year-old single malt scotch whiskey. It hits you hard, but goes down smooth.
Running a mere 80 minutes, "Carnage" still feels longer than it should.
Steve Zaillian's script trims some the novel's fat, keeping the film a lean, mean and frightening beast.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Tepid and slightly disjointed in its portrayal of a fascinating subject and equally fascinating character.
A delightful antidote to the comedic excesses of the season, Ghost Town is smart, sexy fun that should leave no doubt (if there was any) that Ricky Gervais is among the funniest men in film.

The problem with a film that relies heavily on letting musicians talk is that musicians are not often very good talkers. They are eloquent on their instruments but, without them, often resort to inarticulate platitudes.
The entire affair looks and feels like a reality television show minus the cheap drama.
movie_title: LoudQUIETloud: A Film About the Pixies (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Alex Garland has written some of the best science fiction films of this century, so it's startling to see him succeed more as a director than as a writer here.
Like The Interview, Child 44 will be remembered only for the controversy surrounding it.
While Unexpected may be too sunny for its own good at times, its sincerity always shines through.
We Are Still Here is more or less a 90-minute tribute to the superior haunted house features that came before. Great poster, though.
Danny Collins is slightly slight, but it's so competent and sure of itself that it's impossible to dislike. We have entered a new era of Al Pacino.
Joss Whedon sets up the future of the Avengers for the Russo Brothers, but this is no longer exciting. It's exhausting.
Fortunately, thanks to a strong final act and direction that answers the question, "What if Bertolucci directed a Grindhouse flick?", there is entertainment to be found in Alléluia.
Not only has George Miller made an effective return to the wasteland of the Mad Max universe with Fury Road, he has surpassed most action films released ... well ... ever.
There isn't even anything wrong with this being a bad movie; it's just too bad that it is.
The Tribe is just as brutal in its depiction of casual depravity as it is in its bursts of extreme violence. If you can make it past the final five minutes without wincing, more power to you.

James Gunn's first foray into big-budget movie making succeeds despite focusing on characters largely unknown to mainstream audiences and provides some of the most genuinely affecting moments of any Marvel film to date.
There is nothing original and interesting about Chappie. It's a hodgepodge of better science-fiction films from yesteryear whose films have been imitated countless times to no avail.
The new Vacation isn't a trip worth taking. If you thought I could have ended this review with any other sentence, I'm not sure what you were reading.
Goodnight Mommy runs out of potential thrills an hour in before turning into Hostel Part IV.
Director Matthew Vaughn's latest film, Kingsman: The Secret Service, is an attempt at finding a balance somewhere between Austin Powers and James Bond that doesn't quite succeed.
The film never tries to answer the question "At what cost survival?", and as a result, Z for Zachariah succeeds by simply focusing on the question.
Kyle Patrick Alvarez manages to create a mood so disturbing, intense, and believable that it's easy to forget we're watching a movie in spite of all the familiar faces.
The Nightmare had the chance to shed light on a disturbing medical condition, but settles instead for repetition, unnecessary directorial flourishes, and too many unreliable narrators.
Rick Alverson's Entertainment will be admired by just as many people as it will be despised.
Slow West is a beautiful-looking film highlighted by its performances, with just the right amount of humor to make up for the flaws in its story structure.
Sleeping with Other People is the type of R-rated comedy you used to find a single videobox of on Blockbuster's New Release shelf, displayed right beside The Phantom Menace's 15.
The definitive Cobain documentary. There is nowhere else to go from here.
The End of the Tour is a piece for its performers. Jason Segal's performance as Wallace won't just be talked about in the months to come, but in the years to come.
Go into It Follows oblivious of what you're about to see and you'll exit terrified. It lingers.
White God is a breathtaking beast of its own.
It's a total C movie, but to Fuqua's credit, it doesn't try to be anything other than that.
Shock can lead to awe, but in the case of Rudderless, shock leads to "ahhh, they blew it."
Good films create buzz, but movies like Dear White People create conversations.
A coda that goes on for too long, with a smattering of pieces that don't quite fit into any part of the whole puzzle.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation is the best action movie to hit theaters since Mad Max Rockatansky answered our cries back in May, making it the best action movie this summer by far.
Wild Tales is the very definition of a crowd-pleaser.
Tom at the Farm's unwillingness to give us all the answers sets it apart from wannabe psychodramas.
The Hateful Eight is a big, mean movie in a small, isolated setting hidden among a beautiful, beautiful world.
Queen of Earth is an unnerving, intense experience, but you can't turn away from Elisabeth Moss.
Big Eyes is a return to a subdued style from Tim Burton that's been missing for over a decade.
Bringing the action of future Dark Tower novels forward isn't a sin. The sin is not having nearly enough space for it. The film is breathless in all the worst ways as a result.
Never before has a cult documentary contained so much footage of its inner workings
Goat deals with masculinity, fraternities, and PTSD in equal doses, covering all of them with brutal precision and most importantly, success.

What writer and director Kerem Sanga captures so well in First Girl I Loved is high school. What he captures even better is falling in love, or the naïve idea of what it means to be in love as a teenager.

Baena's crime is that he tries to make it a dramedy at the last minute and doesn't come close to earning it. It's a shame, because while the comedy beats are familiar, the uber-talented cast of Joshy give them a new vibe.
Frenzied, kinetic filmmaking is hit or miss, but The Daniels are showcasing their talents as opposed to showing off.
The Birth of a Nation is one of the most confident writing and directorial debuts in recent memory.
What Christine gets right above all else is that it comes at depression from a different angle. Director Antonio Campos evades drone and downpours in favor of '70s soft rock and bright skies.
The Eyes of My Mother is a beautiful nightmare from start to finish
Original thought is in short supply these days. The Greasy Strangler is not.

The Free World works when dealing with the themes found within its title. When we have our freedoms taken away, how difficult is it to get them back. Is it wholly possible? Somewhere along the way, Lew decided such a story wasn't compelling enough.

Other People is an okay movie that could have been better with a little more focus. Come for the performances, but understand that you're just staying for the performances. Oh, and Train's "Drops of Jupiter". Never better.
Concussion aims to be Brian's Song and ends up The Waterboy.
Ryan Coogler accomplished what would have seemed impossible 40 years ago: He got the audience to chant "Creed!" in a Rocky movie.
Early on, Spectre promises to be one of the best Bonds - a reminder that nobody does it better. In the end, it just looks like everything else.
When directed away from the pain and admittedly effective use of violence, The Green Inferno turns into an unintentional laugh riot. U.S. policy and Eli Roth do not mix.
Michael Showalter's Hello, My Name Is Doris is a showcase for Field, reminding us that her comedic chops are just as impactful as her flair for the dramatic.
Knock Knock deserves to be knocked out.
As Above, So Below is a film that gets in its own way as much as dead ends block the paths of its characters.
The only purpose for its existence is potentially giving film students an interesting study in overcompensation.
Bong's Snowpiercer rebels against the norms of summer blockbusters -- overthrowing them all.
The film serves as a reminder that our greatest fear isn't necessarily getting caught in the act; it's getting caught down the line.
People, Places, Things manages to find a pocket within the genre that is light, hopeful, and likeable sans characters transforming into shrews or unredeemable jerks. It's good, and that's just fine.
It's 'second verse, same as the first.' Thank God.
Everything looks artificial and achieved in post-production. Every shortcut is met to save money on budget and time.
A great ripple effect is felt throughout David Mackenzie's Starred Up, a gritty British prison drama that puts most gritty prison dramas to shame.
Larson delivers one of the great performances of 2013.
Director Lowery, in only his second film, offers us a fine modern-day interpretation of classic Terrence Malick.
John Magary's The Mend is a showcase for Josh Lucas, who proves that he's always been a leading man; it's just that Hollywood gave up on him
The Second Mother manages to remain funny throughout its depictions of class, struggle, and motherhood - stories mostly told to death in dramatic fashion.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Come for the movie, struggle through the story, and embrace the tunes.
An average tribute to an extraordinary man.
